div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 5.

lg.l: A Man of Sorrows and with grief acquainted,
He bowed his beauteous head to the rude hands
Of Pilate's hireling bands;
And while beneath their cruel scourge he fainted,
Forgave them,—yearning through his shameful smart
Even with a Brother's heart.
And when upon the infamous Cross they nailed him,
With mocking hatred's mockery and scorn's bitter smile,
Hark how he prayed, ev'n while
Nature's extremest agony assailed him:
'Father, thy mercy even for tow'rds these renew;
They know not what they do.'
And why, thus wronged, did he in spirit trample
Such natural indignation down, as now
Pains, while we read, our brow?
That Love, sublimed by his divine example,
Might reach and so convert that hate in men
Which crucified it then.
For the Great Precept of his Christianity
Was always—'Live in charity; yea, live
To love and to forgive;
That so my spirit may through all humanity
Pass ever downward with a widening birth,
Till Peace possess the earth.'

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 6-7.

lg.l: Trust and treachery, wisdom, folly,
Madness, mirth, and melancholy
Love and hatred, thrift and pillage;—
All are hosed housed in one small village.
And in such a world's mixed being,
Where may Peace, from ruin fleeing,
Find fit shelter and inherit
All the calm of her own merit?
In a barque of gentle motion,
Sailing on the summer ocean?
There worst war the tempest wages,
And the hungry whirlpool rages.
In some lonely new-world bowër,
Hidden like a forest flowër?
There too,—there, to fray the stranger,
Stalks the wild-eyed savage, Danger!
In some Alpine cot, by fountains
Flowing from snow-shining mountains?
There the avalanches thunder,
Crunching all that lyeth under.
In some hermit-tent, pitched lowly
'Mid the tombs of prophets holy?
There, to harry and annoy her,
Roams the infidel destroyer.
In political chambers gilded,
Guarded round with towers high builded?
Change may enter these to-morrow,
And, with Change,—a peerless sorrow.
Then vainly would she thrive by roving
Over wide unpeopled spaces,
Or in wild and virgin places,
Or in hoping, or in loving,
Where thron'd Power is girt with legions;
Having, whether still or moving,
In all times, and in all regions,—
Or in none,—a home of beauty
In the fearless stedfast heart of Duty,
Dwelling ever there, and seeing

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 7-9.

lg.l: Words are the special dies of Thought,
And well they coin mint its gold,
But feeling cannot so be brought
Within their subtlest mould.
With minds on some great theme intent,
We seek to them at length,
And lo, we utter all we meant,
To wonder at their strength.
But when we through their might would wreak
The expression, hardly sane,
Of highest joy or grief—how weaek
We find them, and how vain?
Acting the bliss of feeling, Thought
May [unclear] sieze her very air,
And then, as to her heaven upcaught,
Its transports thus declare:
My joy floods out, like Horeb's rill
Loosed by the Prophet's rod!
My soul, all light, with blissful will,
Rays like a star of God!
But Feeling's happy self, the while,
All silently apart,
May only wear a glowing smile,
And breathe as from the heart.
Or Thought, to imitate her woe,
May wildly cry aloud,
My peace is wasting as I go,
Even like a summer cloud!
My spirit hath so deep a wound,
No cure might be devised,
And shed like water on the ground
Is all that most I prized!
While Feeling's self may only shake
Her weary head, or start
To find how vainly words would break
The silence of her heart.
Or when that holiest spirit, Love,
Plumed with purpureal beams,
Comes like a heaven-descended dove,
To nestle with our dreams;
In vain would Thought in words, though rich
And rare as gems, reveal
That mystic grace of passion which
We feel—and can but feel.
But most, when Music's seraph-fire
Runs kindling through the air,
Making it such as Gods respire,
(And Gods perhaps are there!)
How vainly would the subtlest wit
Word-picture as they roll,
The clouds of glory it hath lit
Like sunrise in the soul!
Like sunrise, when its conquering glow
Smites through the vapors cold,
Till all their ragged inlets flow
With floods of burning gold!
The deep of the Ineffable—
That Deep tha which none may sound,
Pours round us, with its breathing spell—
Immeasurably round.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 9-12.

lg.l: Long ere I knew thee—years of loveless days,
A Shape would gather from my dreams, and pour
The soul-sweet influence of its gentle gaze
Into my being, to thrill it to the core:
Then would I wake, with lonely heart to pine
For that nocturnal Image:—it was thine!
Thine—for though long with a fond moody heed
I sought to match it with the beauteous creatures
I met in the world's ways, 'twas but to bleed
With disappointment; for all forms, all features
Yet left it void of living counterpart—
The shadowy Mistress of my yearning heart.
Thine—for when first seen thou didst seem to me
A being known yet beautifully new!
As when, to crown [unclear] some Sage's theory,
Amid heaven's sisterhoods, into shining view
Comes the conjectured star!—his lucky name
To halo thenceforth with its virgin flame.
But I forget! Far from thy rural home,
Behold, I wander through primeval trees woods
In which but savage things are wont to roam;
Mixing fond questionings with Solitude's
Wild voices, where amid vague glades and dells
Enwrapt in twilight trance her shadowy Presence dwells.
And now the Hunter, with a swollen speed,
Rushes in thunder at my side, but wears
A softened charm mien whene'er its reaches lead
My vision westward,—where pale Fancy rears
Thy wood-nest by that brook, whose murmurs first
As with a flattering heed my love's new gladness nurst.
And with the river's torture, oft a tone
Of that far brook seems blending; accents too,
Of the dear voice there heard—that voice alone
To me unparagoned,—like a silver dew
Honeyed with manna, dropping near me seems,
As oft I listen—lost in rich memorial dreams.
But vain these musings! Though my spirit's bride,
Thou knew'st not of my love! Though all my days
Must henceforth be inevitably dyed
Or bright, or dark, through thee,—this missive says
Thy lot in life is cast, that thou wilt be
Homed with another in the world's fenced ways,
Ere I again may look (if e're again) on thee.
The bardic doom is on encoils me! Poet's[sic] make
Beauty immortal and yet luckless miss
The charms they sing!—martyrs at Fortune's stake!
As if their soul's capacity for bliss
Might else mix earth with heaven, and annul
That want which for its own redemption's sake,
As Love's queen thrones at last, the world-wide Beautiful.
Yet ye wild woods and waters of the earth,
How changed (with all things) shall ye grow to me!
And even the spirit of your summer mirth
Moan pine-like in the winds of memory,
As saddened in the temper of its worth,
Though, as an influence, deepened it may be!
Still shorn of nearer joy, my heart alone
Out in the mother-whole may henceforth seek its own.
Wreathe then the Poet's brows with blossoms bright!
Let waters ever and the sway of trees
Sound through his thoughts as the renewed delight
Of evening flows around him in a breeze
Laden with dying voices—till the night
Enroof him with her starry mysteries!
For thus through Nature can there be for his
First infinite love alone some palingenesis!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 12-13.

lg.l: The world is emptied of that mystic gladness
Which, dwelling round my childhood, o'er it came
In every murmurous game
Played by the winds!—and ever always in my sadness
I look out over its unfriendly face
In vain for some fresh place,
Which now should to Hope seem a fit seem a possible habitation
For that rich light of love wherewith afar
My soul rayed, like a star
Beaming sweet influences from its heavenly station—
Rayed tow'rds all beauty, through the boundless joy
Of the once happy Boy.
'Tis gone too—that frank trust is gone for ever,
Wherewith I afterwards essayed the world,
And first the flag unfurled
Of my own individual endeavour!
Youth's unworn bravery I strive in vain
To gather back again,
If but to know taste once more the heroic feeling
That went then from my heart, as some bold rill
Leaps from its native hill!
But ah! instead, a sense of loss comes pealing
Out of the sunless Past—like a long wail
Heard in the midnight gale!
A sense of vain regrets intents, and hopes yet vainer,
And rich affections wasted, as bestowed
Where Love had no abode!
He only of young life's an absolute gainer,
Who carries with him its unperished bloom
Into an early tomb.
And yet, though coming to this sick conclusion,
My weary soul, methinks, derives some gain
Of strength even from the pain
Attendant upon Memory's transfusion
Over a life so lossful,—strength to know
The personal end of woe:
That gauge of all past suffering to a tittle,
Which leaves us in our central self assured,
As to its brunt inured;
And thence to feel, the future can bring little
That was not typed in what time brought before—
And to expect no more.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 13-15.

div.head: To an Echo on the Banks of the Hunter.

lg.l: I hear thee, Echo! and I start to hear thee
With a strange thrill shock, as from among the hills
Thy voice, reverbing, in swift murmurs near me
Dies down the stream or with its gurgle low
Blends whisperingly, until my bosom thrills
With gentle tribulations that endear thee,
But smack not of the present. 'Twas as though
Some Spirit of the past did then insphere thee
Even with the taste of life's regretted Spring,
Waking wild recollections, to evince
My Being's transfused connection with each thing
Loved, though long since.
It seems but yesterday since last I stood
Beside the Hawksbury even as now I stand
By the swift Hunter, challenging o'er the flood
An Echo, thus; but with a glorious brood
Of hopes then glowing round me, and a band
Of schoolmates and young creatures of my blood
All quick with joyousness beyond command!
And now, with that delightful time, O where
Are those quick joys, glad mates, and hopes of good?
Echo, declare!
Thy voice comes o'er the waters in reply,
To fade as soon! And all those young delights
Decayed (as thy peculiar accents die)
In the dusk valleys of past days and nights,
To be renewed not like thy mystic chide!
And one to the other of those joyous creatures
(Now burthened with their manhoods), in the wide
World's separations have the names and features
So wasted out of mind. And so, at last,
Have all those glorious hopes become but lonely
And dying Echoes of the hollow Past—
All but one only.
And that one, ev'n, round my Being only strays
Like Like a recurring sound. In lonesome ways
Like these it moves me still—not as of yore
Undubiously, though yet its spirit plays
Upon the same old promise: That, when o'er
My Country's homes there shineth riper days,
Her better sons shall learn at length to prize
My lonely voice upon the Past; but more
That to her daughters, as with lustrous eyes
Bathed in the splendors of these self-same skies,
They'll gaze upon my page, even then my Name
Responsives to the ever-loving swell
Of their full souls, and winnowed of its blame,
From Time's dim void (an Echo) thus shall come!
And wheresoever Love and Song may dwell,
So live and die in sweet perpetual doom
Over the flood of ages,—still and still the same
Old claimant with a memorable claim!
And in this Hope, though from its pristine state
Fall'n and adrift, and spoiled of all its bloom,
The recompence for much I lack is great,
For more that may annoy;
Crowning me oft 'mid these dark days of Fate,
With joy—even joy!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 15-19.

lg.l: Fit winding-sheet for thee
Was the upheaving eternal Sea—
Fit dirge the Tempest's slave-alarming roll!
For yokeless as the waves alway
Thy thoughts went sounding forth, as they
Were marshalling to the trumpet—
Were marshalling to the trumpet of the Universal Soul!
Yet tell me, Spirit bright,
Did Nature sorrow not for thee?
That day, veiled not the sun his light
When rolling over Italy?
Paled not the conscious moon, that night,
When gazing down upon the doomful sea?
Feeling for once the drear eclipsive might
Of Death's disastrous spell?
Resolve me—for from under them
Was never reft away before a richer, purer Gem
Than was thy being, wherein love did dwell,
With joy, and natural piety as well,—
Inraying it with a so wildly bright,
So sweetly deep peculiar life
Such as no words may tell!
And never in their day and night
Did Ruin, with the Beautiful at strife,
Work before such horrible spite!
Never trod down at once so much of musical delight!
Thus from an Austral mountain's topmost stone
A Minstrel of that region rude,
Poured for the dead his questioning moan,
Even as from his full heart by times
Gushed forth the impulse-modulated rhymes
And silent then, as he were listening, stood.
But all unanswered was the strain,
Only that in like melancholy mood
Echo, afar, its questions moaned again:
And s[unclear]oon the summery mirth
Of winds and leaves and Nature's murmurous broods
And waters bubbling to the wild refrain
Of wingéd creatures happy from their birth
In man-less mountain solitudes,
Was heard alone;—
Upcoming from the dusky woods
Where in their shadowy depths quick watery glimpses shone:
While down upon that primal scene remote
The sun's unclouded splendors gloried free,
And the young moon, as in a silver boat,
Sat dim, but smiling,—eastward o'er the sea.
Folding his fingers tremulously hard
For passionate complaint, again the Bard
Resumed his wildly mournful lay:
And—"Ah! to be hurried so early away
To death ever clammy and cold as clay—
To death ever blind and deaf and dumb!
In the high noon of a disclouded day,
With much to build within,—without to overcome!"
This was the burthen of the doleful song
That wailed along:
When from a sphered and nameless light
That, as it floated in its mystery by,
Waned like the moon and vanished from his sight,
A stilly Voice made sweet reply:
"Whom the Gods love die young!
Flowers wither away where rank weeds still thrive apace!
Nor is the battle always to the strong,
Nor to the swift for ever sure the race!
Yet if the odors of the flowers remain,
Are they not, even to Regret,
A sweet consolatory gain?
Nor vainly forth was the lost battle set,
Nor the race urged in vain,
Whence flow inspiritng examples yet."
Yes, Poetry and Passion's darling son
Though thou didst walk the world as one
Proscribed by stars inimical to mankind,
While mitred Persecution, dread
And deadly, raged in mortal hate behind!
With Ignorance, her dull slave abhorred;
And who, in mercy as they said,
With many a madly-mystic word,
And vengeful, hot, God-wounding glance upthrown,
Implored the heavens to thunder down
Their Christian wrath on thy devoted head!
Yes, though thus tried—thyself so gentle and kind—
This was for thee the meet memorial crown
By the Great Spirit of all good designed,
That men, to nobler motions born,
And more to a world-wide charity inclined,
Should well reverse their bigot fathers' scorn,
By yearning o'er thy story,
And learning thence how Gnome-like are spirits freedom-blind;
And by glorying in the glory
Of thy love-illumined mind!
All then was well—yea, very well:
Though brief—too brief, here on the earth, thy stay.
Thy Name is with us, for a strengthening spell
To all who, banding against Wrong's bad brood
Would do the unwilling world some lasting good,
Nor idly pass away—
A vapour, nothing more,—a cloudlet grey
By every wind transformed and driven—
A dull and wasting stain in the blue dome of heaven!
And though the heart and brain be food
For hungry Death, where erst the sisterhood
Of thy bright dreams (a Seraph choir) did dwell,
What light around us these, remaining, fling!
For lovelier splendors never fell
In star-showers from Urania's wing,
And flourishing Freedom, in her golden age,
Shall constellate her spheres with glories from thy page!
But hark! yet from her ghostly Cell
Built on that the dubious brink of the Unknown,

l.del: Where Where mystic Craft and abject Terror dwell,

lg.l: Cowled Superstition's sullen bell
Tolls thee to her deepest Hell!
Blind Fury! she alone
Can darkly dare to think,
A soul like thine, though in its earthly shell
Bedimm'd by many an error
Should at her bidding sink
Lossward,—down, in penal terror!
Enough! wherever Love may soar
Beyond that mound which mortals blench to see—
That last low mound on Time's change-beaten shore,
There is thy Spirit now, fire-wing'd and free,
And there a shining dweller shall it be
For evermore!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 19-23.

lg.l: With silent steps behold her I watch thee steal
Over those envious clouds that hid
Till now her thy face, then stand—a seal
Of silver on heaven's mighty lid!
So round me would I have her thy light
In one broad sea of beauty lay;
And who whilst thus she thou rule's't the night,
Would wish the day?
Nor feel his yearning spirit fraught
With sweetly solemn strains of visionary thought?
Love of my childhood! for but when
A child, I loved thee of all things—
Yea, with what happiness I then
Would hail thee? what glad visionings?
And when between us, up the sky,
Obscuring glooms have wildly thronged,
With held in breath and searching eye
How have I longed
For wings, that I might heaveward flee,
To kiss find thy hidden face and ride the dark with thee!
And hence it was that ever forth
My fancy doated more and more,
Upon the wild poetic worth
Of that old tale in Grecian lore,
Which to the head of Latmos gave
Supernal glories, passion-won
By him who in the mystic Cave,—
Endymion,—
Was wont to meet thee night by night,
And drink into his soul the spirit of thy light.
I sadden! Ah, why bringest thou
Yet later memories to my mind?
I would but gaze upon thee now,
As erst, for wonder;—not to find
Dim shades of every morning joy
That once in Windsor's sylvan tracks
Glowed round me (a wild Poet Boy)
Strewn Thus Moving like dun dead racks
Out in the Past, so flecked all o'er [FINAL READING]
With feelings lost, and hopes that know their place no more.
Nor was it thus thy beauty shone
Upon me fewer summers past—
Disheartened, world-distrusting, lone,
And shuddering in Misfortune's blast!
Many that loved me then were nigh,
Of whom now these I may not trust,
And those forget me—or they lie
Dark in the dust!
And never can we meet again,
Loving and loved as then, 'neath thy nocturnal reign
O Cynthia! it would even seem
That portions from our spirits fell,
Like scents from flowers, throughout Life's dream,
And by which clue invisible,
A gathered after-scene of all
Affection builded high in vain,
Is drawn thus in dim funeral
Past us again;
And which, where shadowed most with gloom,
Uncertain Thought is fain to map with spells of doom.
But sober Reason sagelier sager sings:
These vision-mysteries are but
Vague semblances which former things
Hath long imbued us with left with us, even, as put
In act by Memory when again is seen
Again some marked associate sight;
And thence it happens, Orb serene,
Why thou, to night,
Look'st on me from thy native sky
Like an old friend too fond to talk of things gone by.
Let me this night the Past forget!
For though its dying voices be
At times like tones from Eden, yet
Its bosoms too such change for me,
That when but now my thoughts were given
To all I had suffered—loved—and lost!
Turning again mine eyes to heaven,
Year-quenched almost,
I started shook as started with a strange despair impatience strange
To find thee—even thee, smiling unaltered there untouched by change!!
O vain regrets display of secret pride!
My human heart, what irks thee so?
What in the scale of Being tried,
Should weigh thy happiness or woe?
Pale millions, so by Fortune curst,
Have loved for sorrow in the light
Of this yet youthful Moon, since first
She claimed the night,
And thus mature even from her birth,
With pale beam chased the glooms that swathed the infant Earth.[FINAL READING]
And be it humbling too to know
That when this pile of haughty clay,
For ages shall have ceased to glow—
Shrunk to a line of ashes grey!
Which, as the invadingsivesive ploughshare drills
The unrembered burial sward,
The wild winds o'er a hundred hills
May whirl abroad—
That in the midnight heavens thou
Shalt hang thy unfaded lamp and smile serene as now.
Nay, more than this; could even th[unclear] those,
The Edenites, who sorrowed here
Ere Noah's tilted ark arose,
Or Nimrod chased the bounding deer—
Wherever sepulchered, could they
The rigid bonds of death and doom,
Now, for a amoment, shake away—
Down on their tomb
Thy watchful face they still might see,
Just as they dying lift it, gazing solemnly.
But shall my thoughts thus [unclear] widely range
And I therein no profit know?
Seeing that wither, waste, and change
Must every form that earth can grow,
Shall I not ever henceforth aim
To shun in act, in thought control,
Whatever dims the heaven-born flame—
The essential Soul
I feel within, and which must be
A living Light when thine is quenched eternally.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 23-24.

lg.l: 'Tis long ago—but oft, even yet,
The death-calm visage of a Child
Comes shrouded from the past, to re-beget
An ancient sorrow wild!
The face of him, our gentle-eyed
Henry—the little one that died.
I heard an outcry in the night,
And then a deep sad my Father's voice, that said
'Tis even so; my boding heart was right—
Our poor sick Boy is dead!
And yet my sense of loss but seemed
Like some vague wild thing I had dreamed.
But when that solemn night was past,
The feeling of how wide a sea
Had in the ghostly silence rolled its vast
Black depth depth 'twixt him and me,
Even as I breathed it, damped the air
With Life's first terrible Despair!
I sought a lonely place, and lay
Prone on the ground for very woe!
And what, O God! if my wild grief that day
Did in its wildness show,
That we, on Time's change-beaten shore,
Had parted—never to meet more!
But no! that cannot—cannot be!
In soul we yet must meet again—
This love, my Brother, mourning yet for thee,
Can ask it not in vain!
Nor Heaven design a rent more fell
Than were reunion though in Hell!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 24-25.

lg.l: To cheer my lonely dwelling shed,
Upon its humble roof is heard,
As duly I retire to bed
A little nightly Bird:
Hark! ever there the creature sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
Beneath the silent shining stars,
And while the moon pays down her light,
Although no wiery wiry thraldom bars
The freedom of its flight,
There nightly thus it every sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
And while I listen, there will come
Dim memories of the Past, that say
Upon my Childhood's happy home
A little shrilling lay
Was nightly heard, like this that brings
Its iterant but melodious things.
I know not if it was in kind
The same with you peculiar Bird,
But on my Father's roof I mind
How often we had heard,
A voice like this without, that sings
Those iterant but melodious things.
But ah! for him, the parent sage
Whose Seven then met his nightly call;
And him, whose cheek of tenderest age
Was fondest kissed of all!
I murmur—while the creature sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
And now too, there's a Grave new made
'Mid scenes to Memory unknown,
And there cold stranger hands have laid
Our manly-hearted John!
I weep—while still the creature sings
Its iterant but melodious things.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 26.

lg.l: A little light, heat, motion, breath—
Then silence, darkness, and decay,
Are all that difference life and death
In him that weareth clay:
But Time's one drop 'twixt that and this,
Ah! what a gulf of doom it is!
The cheek is fair, the eye is bold,
The ripe lip like a berry red:
Then the shroud clothes them;—thus behold
The Living and the Dead!
And how Time's last cold drop serene
Swells to eternity between!
Yet not for horror, nor to weep:
But through the solemn dark to see
That Life, though swift, is wonder-deep,
And Death the only key
Which lets to that mysterious height
Where Earth and Heaven in God unite.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 26-29.

lg.l: Progress! 'tis the life that rages
Through the world's predestined ages,
Never resting, ever breasting
The unrefluent waves of Time,
At the Almighty Word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealing ever
Onward!
Have the blasts of sorrow worn thee,
Have the rocks of danger torn thee,
And thus shifted, wreck-like drifted,
Wouldst thou find a port in Time?
Vain the quest! That word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealeth ever
Onward!
Hast thou done all loving duty,
Hast thou clothed thy soul with beauty,
And wouldst rest then, wholly blest then,
In some sunny lapse of Time?
Vain the hope! That word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealeth ever
Onward!
Hast thou won the heart of Glory,
Hast thou charmed the tongue of Story,
And wouldst pause then for applause then,
Underneath the stars of Time?
Vain the lure! That word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealeth ever
Onward!
Truth and Virtue hast thou wrought for,
Faith and Freedom hast thou fought for,
And then shrinkst, for thou thinkest
Paid is all thy debt in Time?
Vain the thought! That word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealeth ever
Onward!
Loss is Gain's propelling neighbor,
Power produced is farther labor;
All our caring and preparing
For a quiet stand in Time,
Breaks, wave-like, at that word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealing ever
Onward!
Form is soul, and soul projection
Tow'rds an ultimate perfection,
Never standing, still expanding
Underneath the suns of Time,
Moved,—quickened by that word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealing ever
Onward!
From endeavor to endeavor,
Journeying with the hours for ever,
Or aspiring, or acquiring,
This, O Man! is life in Time,
Urged by that primal word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealing ever
Onward!
Nor repine thou, nor faint doubtward,
That it is so: the great whole Outward
With its raying worlds, unstraying,
Thunders through the vast of Time,
Struck by that same sole word sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealing ever
Onward!
And as soul is form's projection
Tow'rds an ultimate perfection,
Nought from good can interclude man
Either in or out of Time,
So long as that command sublime—
God's great one word,
Silent never, pealingeth ever
Onward!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 29-30.

lg.l: The only faithless thing is Man,
Whose evil plan
Excludes Man's brotherhood:
All else are trusty to the rod
And sireship of Almighty God,
But Man's in's lordly mood.
The honest moon pays down her light
In silver bright,
The sun in burning gold;
The stars above the hills that rise
Like thought-informed and earnest eyes,
Keep compact as of old.
The birds their pristine glees prolong—
The flowery throng
Bloom as they bloomed alway;
The beasts amid the fields than won
Are loyal to their mould as on
Creation's earliest day.
'Tis man alone—dishonest man,
Who schemes a plan
Excluding brotherhood!
He only, with disnatured mind,
Becomes the Tyrant of his kind:
He! in his lordly mood.
But shall there yet not be yet a time
When this stern rhyme
Shall be no longer true?
When Man Love shall re-create the good
That stable guileless kept the brotherhood
He Man erst in Eden knew?
There shall! The very dream that we
Might faithful be,
Assures us that there shall!
When Freedom to her mission true,
Shall commonise the all-grasping lordly few,
So to enable By elevating all!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 30-31.

lg.l: When with a philosophic quest
Creation is surveyed,
The Hand of God must be confessed
In all that he has made.
We see it through the simplest means
Attaining subtlest ends,
Where nothing wrongly supervenes,
And nothing vainly lends.
We see it—dimly, it may be,
But there it is—the line
That ever points to unity
In manifold design.
As when a living leaf we place
Betwixt us and the sun,
All through it, with a vein-like trace
The life is seen to run:
Seen ribbing from one central spine
In modes so surely fit,
As still to be, through every line,
In final union knit.
Yes, thus, when with a heedful quest
Creation is surveyed,
The Hand of God must be confessed
In all that he has made.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 31-33.

lg.l: Strong trust of the bold Sailor
On the shores of sudden storm,
How massive is its structure,
And how able is its form!
Old ocean's bed rock gripping
With the hurricane's tug 'twill cope,
And therefore tis the emblem held
Of Man's eternal hope.
Where never plummet sounded
By the bleak and stormy steep,
Like a thunder bolt down rushing
It is shot into the deep:
Down where some mute sea monster
Its so hideous bulk uprears,
And mightiest Silence drowned hath lain
For many a thousand years.
In some famed bay of battle
When 'tis plunged with sullen roar—
In the Nile, in Naverino,
Or by Danish Elsinore—
How meetly there it slumbers,
Deep beneath the sounding waves,
Amid the bones of gallant tars
In Glory watery graves!
In the bright and land-locked harbour,
The weary voyäge o'er,
When only pleasant breezes
Breathe sweet welcome from the shore,
Its noble form down dropping
To its quiet bed below,
Gives signal to the first glad boat
That beachward pants to go.
In the storm thou firm-fixed surety—
Thou strong helper in the storm—
Even a child, when first beholding
All the fitness of thy form,
Might well divine the dangers
Wherewithal 'tis thine to cope,
And take thee as an emblem meet
Of Man's eternal hope.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 33-34.

lg.l: When Joshua in the days of old
Stood forth on Jordan's western bank,
And past the flood that backward rolled
His host came dryshod, rank on rank;
The Warrior Angel of the Lord—
A glorious shining Creature! bared
Before him there a flaming sword,
And thus the mind of God declared:
Lo, I am with you! Here shall dwell
My chosen People—here, I plant thee, Israel!
The walls of Jericho are strong,
And ribbed throughout with many a tower;
And yet her Monarch's arméd throng
Stands trembling round his throne of power:
For circling still those walls about,
Behold the Ark of God is borne!
Blow trumpets, blow! shout Israel, shout!
'Tis done—and from the earth uptorn,
At once they shatter and disform
Like the crude cloud-built bastions of a bursting storm!
Five kings at Gibeon are met—
Five mighty kings of ancient name—
And they are boasting there to set
A blood-red bound to Joshua's fame!
But the sun stands fast on Gibeon's hill,
And the moon is fixed o'er Ajalon,
That Israel's host, in vengeance, still
Flood-like may spread and thunder God's victory on!
And where are now those kings? Yon cave
Hides them in vain—or hides them only as their grave!
From Merom, hark! there spreads a roar
As of a from a tempest-troddentrampled sea,
For confluent there, together pour
All Canaan's might and royalty!
But all this war how little worth,
When tried by that prevailing sword
In Israel's front far flaming forth,
For what are numbers to the Lord?
That multitudinous array
Breaks, melting as it rolls, like morning mist—away!
Thus Israel in the days of old,
Led on by Joshua and the Lord,
Like a devouring tempest rolled
Destructive o'er each race abhorred:
Each people sold into the hand
Of shame, by Him, the only wise,
When through iniquity their land
Grew leprose in his holy eyes!
And thus my Harp records in rhyme
His mighty works and wonders of the olden time.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 35-37.

lg.l: "Who would not be a Poet?"—thus I read
In thy proud Sonnet, my poetic Friend;
And then the streamy measures led
My utterance on—But, at the end,
The question made me ponder,
And out of mind let wander
The Poet, seeing that, for ever, he
A Man of Sorrows is foredoomed to be:
Yet unto this much my assent was given—
There is not under the whole dome of, cannot be,—under all heaven,
Aught happier in itself than the witch Poetry!
What is not spell-touched by her dream-wing'd Powees?
See those happy creatures, the Spring flowers,
Even where they freshest grow—
Even where they richest glow—
Blest into beauty by the genial Hours!
There as they blisfully breathe away
There odorous spirits, do but we
While strolling near them leisurely
On some fair holyday,
Their worth rehearse
In eloquent verse,
O are not they then—even they,
Yet fresher for the might,
And richer for the light,
And sweeter—howe'er sweet they be—
Sweeter for the angel--breath of raptured Poetry?
Even Love itself is earthy—till betimes
Upon her bosom, in its mystery,
We lay it, like a wayward child,
Hushing its nature wild
With lullabies drawn from its own history
Through all the heart's most golden climes:
Fond lullabies, set forth in free
And fancy-honey[unclear]ed rhymes.
Rich fit rhymes—the meet
Wing-plumes for love-born Melody,
When Wooed forth abroad by airs and odors sweet,
And with all morning things that freshest be
Glossed and dewed over, as with jewell'ry;
And eke (its Hesper orient glory to complete)
With every hue the setting sun sublimes
Touched, like a cloud,—and resonant inwardly
With every flowing tone that sweetliest primes
The peans of Nature, who herself we see
Smile always happiest, when her music chimes
With the music of passionate Poetry.
But—"who'd not be a Poet?" Here I pause
Forebodingly, my Poet-friend,—because
"To see all beauty with his gifted sight,"
To love, like him, with all the soul,
To be when life is morning-bright
The very Creature of Delight—
Delight beyond control;
Is Is still to be in a like degree,
Too Too sensible of misery,
And loss, and slight, and all the weeping Shapes of Dole.
There was an earnest-thoughted Boy,
Who with a secret thrill
Of lonely but hopeful joy,
Had to himself proposed thy question—till
His swelling heart and throbbing head
Flowed with the tunefulness he coveted.
He loved to muse alone, this studious Creature,
Yet was not solitary, but apart,
For to his eye, and ear, and mind, and heart,
Each aspect, every tone, and trick of Nature
Was still a grand, or sweet, or beautiful feature:
Yea, all!—her veriest simplicities—
Bird, insect, beast,—brooks, flowers, and trees—
All in their final influences,
Even with his body's growth, nourished his Spirit's stature.
And thus accomplished only, to the fight
Of Life's dishonest battle did he come;
To meet front instead of Valor, mean Despite,
And Envy aye in Emulation's room;
To see unblushing Fortune's minions doom
To obloquy, through some repute unholy
Or to some vile and miserable estate,
All such as would not trample on the lowly
And basely glorify the falsely grate great;
Or for a mental hireling's devil-pay
Defend the oppressor and belie the oppressed:
And so from all he turned at length away
Even those (the noble few) he loved the best,
To sorrow in proud silence and apart
Over dead Hope—and find a vast unrest
Even in the loneliest ways, through weariness of heart.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 38.

lg.l: Do you dream of the future, my Boy?
That future is dreaming of you!
Summery seasons so heart-full of joy,
Drear weintery periods too:
All thronged with shadowy hopes and fears,
All streaked with smiles, and gleamed with tears,
The sweet and bitter of coming years:
Dream you of these? They of you
In the spirit of fortune are all dreaming too.
Or comes to your slumber some thought
Of your mystical life in the Past,
Like a far-reaching utterance [unclear] a tone of eternity caught [NOT ALL CODED]
As out of 'twere through a pau lull in Time's blast;—
A thought of loving Ones afar
Who blest you in some other Star,
That rolleth through heaven its golden car?
Love them again! Just as fast
As time flyeth, the Present becometh the Past.
Nay, the Present, the Past, the To-come,
Are nothing, sweet dreamer, I see,
But Time's three-in-one, since Being's their home—
That Being which ever must be!
Whence thou,—I,—all,—our stand have each
Where never but in seeming reach,
The wild waves breaking on Death's dark beach!
Dreaming or dead—with all three
In our essence, for ever—for ever are we!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 43-49.

lg.l: From the crude records which mysterious Time
Hath graven on the crag-boned hills, and strewn
In crumbled fragments, and embedded deep,
On wild sea sores shores, in dim dells, watery chasms,
And in the death-dark bowels of the Earth,
Where never sunshine, since Creation's dawn,
Hath fallen in its golden splendor down,
We learn that she, at dateless intervals,
Hath been the plastic and predestined mould
Of awfullest changes. And from these again,—
Reading their crude significance, forthright more and more
Into coherencey, more and more,—we father wondering find as [NOT ALL CODED]
That Her dark womb, through immemorial eras vast tracts,

l.add: Of [unclear] days years so countless that they ghostly seem,

lg.l: Hath also teemed with still successive births
Of vegitable prophecies of spirit,
Ever ascending to their own fulfilment;
And thence with sentient natures, linking on
In strict organic sequency, from forms
Of lowest power and purpose,—on and on,
To higher and highest.
Thus her quickening mass
Quickened yet more, till knotted reptile things,
Stolid, yet frightful through mere multitude,
(Even as beheld only in thought), have swarmed
O'er all her clammy disc, as vile worms clothe,
In horrible mockery of both life and death
An else-stark corpse; or beings unto which
The monstrous serpent of the Indian wastes
Were but a minim, in her miry lap
Have wallowed, snorting in their ponderous joy—
Beings enormous! but in function low,
And gross in shape,—yea, ugly as enorm
And evermore and pre-doomed to perish, when
Her altering surface grew the meet abode
For things of greater beauty. Whether wrought
Into such meetness by set laws of change,
For ever active, and thence through all time
Distributing their forces; or by some
Mystical energy at work within,
Of Demogorgon kind; or by the sweep
Of sudden cataclysms wild and vast;
Or by the upburst of internal fires,
Instant and universal.
First emerged
Mountains abrupt, like those upon the moon,
Scarred through with fissures out of which there seethed
A white volcanic heat; while spongy growths
Of cypress-dark and flowerless forests, filled
Vast valleys with a damp and noisome shade,
But luminous at intervals with drear
Avernian lakes, that blackened under storms
Drifting aloft, or imaged back the bulk
Of bat-like monsters, flying o'er; or glassed
(Along their low shores shadowing out) the huge
Unwieldy masses of some mammoth herd,
As into the dim spaces of the dense
And bordering woods it passed, and onward then
Crashed, munching as it went. And yet on this
So lonesome scene, the sun arose as now,
True to his season, and the moon unveiled
Her pale face over it night after night,
Bevied about with all her golden train
Of stellar glories raying influence down.
Yea thus, for countless centuries, beneath
The fulgent host of heaven, did all the bare
And slopeless hills show ghastly in their light,
And the dull waters gleam: although as yet,
Through all these patient periods immature,
No soul intelligent, save God himself,
Might know or visit them—God their author.
But lo, But at last,
In jubilant ascension, Man, and all
The tribes of living creatures over which
He reigneth absolute, with comelier forms
Of higher mould cast, and inwardly endued
With spirits and faculties that flourished forth
To finer issues and to ends more nice,
Gave to their mother Earth's time-tempered orb
That worth and excellence which now are hers.
Then, on the hills, the hunter's voice went forth,
And, in the valleys, the glad chaunt of birds
Chimed sweetly with the gurgling interflows,
And musical motions, manifold and mixed,
Of rivers in their broad abundant flow
Through boundless depths of bloomy boughs, all tossed
And billowing in the breeze; and Echoes, housed
In rocky steeps, and caves, and twilight dells,
Made merry with the cheerful noise that came
Mellowed by distance, out of lowing glens
And multitudinously bleating vales,
And [unclear] prairies In large scopes,—lying all within the each broad
Allotted heritage that stretched around
The low-roofed homesteads of an early world;—

l.add: Low-roofed, but staunch,—and welcome-fullfraught, as seen

lg.l: Bosomed in trees from which ripe golden globes
Hung clustered, while about them rippled deep
Glad fields of rustling corn: till hence at length,
Through many all these meet channels working, Nature taught
Music to Art; and answering to a want
Hence too created, Poetry arose
Out of the dayspring like a morning star
Upon the awakened spirit of delight;
And thence descending in her influence, grew
More intimate and plastic,—till at last
Semblance idealised in hues, or wrought
From the rude rock into a life which spake
The language of a immutable Loveliness,
Adorned the abodes of Learning, and the shrines
Of Worship, and of Virtue;—Sister Arts,
Three Sister Arts in fellowship divine—
A triune glory of exalted Soul.
But dare we think the awful laws of Change
From good to better, still, though over roads
So rough in seeming— have even yet an end? [NOT ALL CODED]
That Earth is Man's for ever? His and theirs,
The tribes o'er which pre-eminent he reigns
As King—his one true Kingship? No: the Hours
That shall behold her the prepared abode
For new successions in the Scheme of Life,
May even now—like a long flight of storks
Or ere it loom in view,—up, where the waves
Of ocean welter in the spectral haze
On heaven's apparent verge;—thus, even now,
May these upon their dim but destined way
Be winging world-word, through the eternal clouds
That hide the future in their pregnant folds.
But, granting this, from whence, it may be asked,
Might spring these novel Orders? Even from where
All that preceded them in time's long tract
Have hitherto sprang life-ward:—from the womb
Prolific of that Spirit of the World
Called Nature, and wherein, even from the first,
In virtual preparation shall have slept
Their causes,—darkling; but awaiting so
The evoking word of God! And what besides
Were needed, for thrice greater things,—the births
Of mightiest Systems, than that mighty potent Word
Which the mind heareth, as expressed through laws
Whose sure results are but the far-produced
Decisions of His will,—as fore-designed,
Will and design in an omnicient Spirit
Being co-incident.
Or rather, what
I would adumbrate in this serious song,
Were but progressive changes in the sum
And complement of that Divine Idea
Whereof the Earth's so solid-seeming mass
Is, with its fleshly populations whole,
The vesture,—yea, the tactual shape, and thence
The visual sign in manifold reflection,
As ever forth fulfilling, more and more,
Its part in that great Sequence which ensures
The prospering intercourse of all the worlds:
Even as a human thought—so far as what
Is finite, and imperfect therefore, may
With Infinite compare,—as knowledge grows
Before it, and combines all congruant things,
A necessary progress undergoes
In its accruing unity with Truth.
But come what changes may, yet is the Soul,
As individualised in all mankind,
Beyond the swoop of chance, and lifted high
Out of the wasting whirl of brute Appearance,
When thence eliminated. She, complete
In her sole self- being, evermore aspires
An ultimatede of all that went before—
A Spirit of Thought, and thence of that prime Cause
Wherby the world itself began and is.
And thus derived,—a Virtue purer far
Than that invisible ethereal fire—
That vital spirit of the world that which breathes
Through NatureBeing's boundless lungs, she cannot know
Or darkness, or corruption; but must be
A missioned Liberty, and thence endued
With powers of self-developement, that break
All bondage! Yea, ancestrally a spark
From God's own brightness, goes she world-ward forth
To die not, but to clothe for evermore
Her mighty life and wondrous faculties
In robes of beauty and of use, and all
The comforting integuments which sense
Weaves for her wearing, in the loom of Time,
Out of the hoards and harvests of the earth;
And then by transmigration made through that
New birth which takes Death's semblance, in the adapted called Death, in the adopted worth
And garniture of many or all of those
Innumerable other orbs, that strew spangle thick
The neighboring heaven with seats of being,—such
As host on host yet farther forth, enrich
Infinite spaces, populous alike
With kindred glories bosomed all in Him!
As [unclear] [unclear] being indeed the million-featured modes
Of His Almighty Being omniscient Power;—each several mode
A shining link in one eternal chain
Of progress—to Perfection.
Here we rest
Secure in soul. In secular safety too,
Here rest we,—satisfied; that come what may
Of change to Earth herself, though such as yet or unto those

l.add: Her kindred glories which compose so bright
A sisterhood in heaven,—though such as yet

lg.l: Shall beat her them into ruin and involve
Her Their death in seeming; still, in sure reserve,
For her each some restoration must abide
In the unfailing consciousness of God,
And that divine necessity which makes
Creation and Advancement evermore
Link onward through all being: wherefore She,

l.add: And They, though after some dread shock of change

lg.l: Though Long lying shrouded, shall would shall again awake,
And yet again,—wake jubilant, to hear
His far-off trumpet through the dark of doom
Calling her them up into a state yet more
Exalted, as yet nearer to his own
Internal excellence and central peace.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 50.

lg.l: No Flower more beautiful, none lovelier blows
In Natures fragrant bosom. Even where
Its With rarest living gems some Garden rare
Flames like heaven's pavement, fairest amongst those
It bloometh still— For ever blooms the ruddy regal Rose!
And this was given (to bear with me afar)
By One whose image, ever always, like a star
When ocean-mirrored, in my fancy glows.
And daily henceforth,—always ever at this hour,—
I'll look on it though faded, and so reap
Rich solace from the Past: for then the Power
Of mutual passion shall around me keep
In mystic presence, and upon me shower
Memories that bless me even while I weep.

div.p: The note "Final copies" on p. 51 applies to this poem.
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 50-51.

lg.l: Nightly I watch the Moon with silvery sheen
Flaking the city house-tops—till I feel
Thy memory, Rosa, like a presence steal
Down in her light; for always in her mien
Thy soul's similitude my soul hath seen!
And as she seemeth now a guardian seal
On On Heaven's far bliss, upon my future weal
Even such thy truth is—radiantly serene.
But long my fancy may not entertain
These bright resemblances—for lo, a cloud
Blots her away! and in my breast the pain
Of absent love recurring, pines aloud!
When shall I look in thy bright eyes again,
Oh, my belovèd! with like sadness bowed?

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 51.

lg.l: Why tower my spirits, and what means this wild
Disturbance Commotion at my heart?—this dreamy chase
Of possible joys that glow like stars in space?
Now feel I even to all things reconciled,
For As all seem were one in spirit. Rudely up-piled
Brown hills grow beautiful; a novel grace
Exalts the moorland's once [unclear] for unmeaning face;
The river that, like a pure mind beguiled,
Grows purer for its errors, and the trees
That fringe its margin with a dusky shade
Seem robed in fairy wonder: and are these
Thus raised to me Exalted thus, because with me surveyed
By one sweet soul whom well they seem to please,—
Here at my side,—an almost stranger Maid?

div.p: The meaning of the heading "(The Crown of Nature.)" above the series title is unclear.
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 51-52.

lg.l: Now sunny as the noontide heavens are
The eyes of my sweet Friend, and now serene
And chastely shadowy in their maiden mien;
Or dream-power, sparkling like a manifold star,
Fills all their blue depths,—rapping me afar
To where, in the rich Past, through Song is seen
Some sovereign beauty—Knighthood's mystic Queen,
Pluming with love the iron brows of War!
Bright eyes before, with subtle lightning glance,
Have kindled all my being into one
Wild tumult; but a charm thus to enhance
My heart's love loyalty before till now had none!
And can this witchcry be the work of chance?
I know not—I but know my rest is gone.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 52.

lg.l: A vast and shadowy hope breaks up my rest
Unspoken;—nor does dares even my pen dare to write
How my pent spirit pineth day and night
For one fair Being with whom I might be blest!
And ever with vague jealousies possessed,
The more I languish, feeling these may so
Oppress Affection, that for very woe
She longs at last to die, deep buried in my breast!
O for a brimmer beaker of the wine of Love,
Or a deep draught of the Lethèan wave!
The power a mutual passion to emove,
Or that repose which sealeth up the grave!
Yet these my bonds are blameless: one more wise
Had dreamt away his freedom, dreaming of her eyes.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 52-53.

lg.l: Her Image haunts me! Lo, I muse at even,
And straight it gathers from the gloom, to make
My soul its mirror; which (as some still lake
Holds pictured in its depths the face of heaven)
Through Through the hushed night retains it: when 'tis given
To take a warmer presence and incline
A glowing cheek all blushfully cordially to mine,
Saying—'The heart for which thou long hast striven
With looks so fancy-pale, I grant thee now;
And if for pity, yet more for Love's sweet sake,
My lips shall seal this promise on thy brow.—"
Thus blest in sleep, who —oh! would not weep care to wake,
When the cold real from his belief must shake
Such vows, like blossoms from a shattered bough?

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 53.

lg.l: She loves me! From her own bliss-breathing lips
The live confession came, like rich perfùme
From crimson petals bursting into bloom!
And still my heart at the remembrance skips
Like a young lion, and my tongue too trips,
As drunk with joy! while every object seen
In life's diurnal round, wears in its mien
A clear assurance that no doubts eclipse [FINAL READING]
And of the common things of nature now
Are like old faces flushed with new delight,
Much more the consciousness of that rich vow
Deepens the beauteous and refines the bright,
While throned I seem of on Love's divinest height
'Mid purple glories turbaning its brow!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 53-54.

lg.l: There is one Spot my greatful heart could deem
A lingering vestige of old Paradise,
Albeit not much to captivate the eyes
Of ornament is there. And when I dream
Of Love and Happiness Pleasure, its dear objects gleam
Amid the worldly troubles that arise
To cloud me my life, like bright glimpses of the skies
Smiling through storm-glooms that across them gleam stream,
I gaze upon it from the neighboring hills,
And like a warbler of the forest, when
The spirit of joy its artless being thrills
Even to the pinions,—my wild fancy then
Thitherward hurries on delighted plumes,
All sweetened to return, as from a Bower of Blooms.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 54.

lg.l: There is a trying spirit in the drift
Of human life, apportioning the prize
(In quality or color, shapes or size)
That each one seeketh to that seeker's gift.
Hence must he suffer many a perilous shift
Who into fame by martial deeds would rise;
Hence look at liberty with eagle lion eyes
Must he who'd make the march of man more swift:
Hence Heaven's best crown, more glorious than the sun,
Is only gained by dying for our kind;
And hence too, True Love's highest meed is won
Only through agonies of heart and mind!
Such, Rosa, is the fate, (and therefore ours)
Of all whom Love would crown with truth joy's faith's divinest flowers!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 54-55.

lg.l: The voyage to the haven of True Love
Was ever stormy since the world began,
Or Story from its earliest fountain ran;
Teaching us truly that the Gods approve
In the superior destinies of Man
Only what most the noblest hearts shall move
Hence was Leander's life so brief a span,
Who, weltering a mortal while above
The The bursting wave, sent on his soul to where
The Beauty of Sestos from her watch-tower's height
Looked for his coming through the troubled air,
Nor knew that he had died for her that night!
Hence Sappho's fatal leap (the cause the same)
Hence too was Petrarch's heart the martyr of his flame.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 55.

lg.l: Loss follows gain, and sadness waits on mirth,
And much is wasted where too much is given;
We cannot fully have our joy on earth
Without diminishing our joy in heaven.
Envy clogs merit; madness neighbors wit;
Stale is their gladness who were never sad;
And Divès in this fleshly life, 'tis writ,
Recieved his good things, Lazaras his bad.
Thus, Rosa, o'er the waves of many things
My searching mind, even like a ship, is tossed,
And from the quest this only Inference brings:
That True Love in its earthly stage course is crossed,
Lest by dull worldly usage it should be
Lowered in its final immortality

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 55.

Hath but one well of [unclear], in the believing Past,[...]

lg.l: "At once disclosed
The picture of the past presents itself
Minute yet vivid, such as it is seen
In the last moments by a drowning man."

body.p:
"There are few psychological phenomena more interesting
or more worthy of scientific investigation than the one here
alluded to,—the presentation to a man in a drowning state,—
and not, as far as I am aware, to a man in a drowning state,—
and not, as far as I am aware, to a man dying in any other
way,—of innumerable acts and occurrences in a succession
so rapid, that his whole life appears to be reflected in his last
moments. There have been several examples of this in our times,
according to the relations of men who have been resuscitated out
of a drowning state; and one of them is of such unquestionable
authenticity and value, that some claim may perhaps be
advanced in the interest of Science to have it duly recorded."

Many years after the ensuing Poem was written, I found the
above verses in Henry Taylor's Edwin the Fair; and the prose
remarks which follow them occur in a note upon the same. See
Moxon's Edition of 1845.

lg.l: I was once so deeply drowned,
That when the drag my body found,
'Twas void of motion, void of breath,
And to sensation dead as Death.
In a languid summer mood,
Lo, I plunge into a flood,
That to the low sun's slanting beams
Gleameth only quiet gleams,
Each, with a wide flicker, sheeting
Up from its still floor—fast and fleeting:
Even such a flood as one would say
Could never, or by night or day,
Have drenched a man's warm life away.

l.add: Though oft indeed, things deadly will

lg.l: But what are these, down in its bed,
That trail so long and look so red,
Moving as in conscious sport—
Are they weeds of curious sort?※
But I'll dive to them, and see
Into all their mystery.
Down I dive.—A plenteous crop!
Some shall with me to the top:
For here there is too dim a light
To show their character aright.
I wind them in my arms, intent
To root them up in my ascent:
But they resist me, and again
I tug them with a stronger strain!
Full well, I trow, they hold their own,
Gripping fast each bedded stone
With their tuby roots, that go
Thence down through the stiff slime below.
—Well, the upshot is, that I
Must leave them—But in vain I try!
Fierce as lightning on my brain
Smites the dread truth—I try in vain!
Yea, more and more, in coils and flakes,
Like long blood-red water snakes
The deadly things around me clasp,—
The more I tug, the more they grasp!
My pent breath, growing hot and thin,
Explodes with a long dull booming din,
While through my unclenched teeth, the wave
Comes drenching! Is there none to save?
None near to see—to guess—to trace
Under the water's gleaming face,
As by sudden whirl-rings shown,
Or rush of bubbles upward thrown,
The dread extremity of one
Thus fastened down? Ah! is there none?
Wild as vain my struggles grow—
Horror! horror! is it so?
Hope gives up her ghost—Despair!
And as a fish dies in the air,
In its element deep drowned,
I am dying. All around
The long weeds, erst so deeply red,
Look, even where nearest, grey as lead,
As 'mid them, settling down, I sway
To and fro, and fast away
Life keeps bubbling—bubbling aye
Through my cold lips wide agape,
And stiffening into that white shape
They take at last (when done with breath)
In the rigid face of Death.
And now, while sullen drummings make
My spirit through mine ears to ake,
Life-long memories, interwrought
With all I ever felt or thought;—
Sacred fancies, hidden long
Lest the world should do them wrong—
Held back feelings that for years
Just below the source of tears
Have lain perdu, like gems that 'bide
In the bright sands unespied,
Over which some Orient stream
Floweth with a golden gleam;—
Taking instantaneous wings,
With a million other things,
All at once—(yet each its own
Shape keeping—marked, as if alone)
All, thick interthronging, press
Through my drowning consciousness!
All in the same instant, so
Do they come, and do they go:
Leaving one mixed thought to reign
Sole within my failing brain—
Full of pity, full of pain!
One mixed thought of how my doom
Must wrap my Mother in its gloom;
And give my Sire to hold his breath
For anguish, hearing of my death;
And to all home relations be
Always a dread memory;
And wound one fond heart to the core
In the wide world evermore:
Making Love to her appear,
Even when alive and near
Too fatal, and too full of fear—
Or seen through tears by Memory shed,
But the wild manes of a dead
Ideal of the soul—a glow
That like a sunset, long ago,
Went down into the dark of wo.
Lastly, a drear stupor, blent
With a cold comfortless content,
Into one mass of clammy clay
Kneads body and mind. Thus drenched away,
With one faint shudder, one last throe,
Life stagnates, and its shell lies low,
Swaying weed-bound to and fro,
Void of all feeling, as of breath—
How die we, if this be not Death?
Ah, what thrilling, thrilling pain
Kindles through my heart and brain!
Ah, what horrors vague and fell,
Come shadowing o'er me as from hell!
Ah, those sudden glares of light,
They fall like firebrands on my sight!
Ah, what vast and heavy world
Is all at once upon me hurled,
Massing into one immense
Oppression, every tortured sense!
Yes: I now remember well
How my sudden fate befell!
And are we then, in death's grim thrall,
Thus conscious of our funeral?
But where are they who most should mourn
When my bier is graveward borne?
With her whose face I yearn to see—
Where are they? and where is she?
Where the crape-trimm'd followers all?
Where the coffin and the pall?
Or do Death and Nature strive
Within me?—Is the drowned alive?

div.p:
※ This kind of water-weed is somewhat rare, and it is well
that it is so. It is of a deep blood color, very long, pipy, and
sensitive. So sensitive, indeed, is it, that if any part of it
be touched, while protending in the water with a wavy sinuous motion,
—say by a stick pushed down for the purpose, the whole of
its length beyond the part thus touched will begin to lap
about it in regular coils,—the result being nearly the same
in the event of its coming into contact with the limb of a bather.
And from this curious circumstance, it is a weed which is
exceedingly dangerous to weak swimmers where it happens
to abound, as in some parts of the South Creek near Windsor—
having concurred, in fact, in the drowning of many such.
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 63-68.

lg.l: A Rhyme of Love in loneliness—
But sound and sweet, though lonely;
And eke of Hope in unsuccess—
But thence the braver only.
Blissless am I, except in this
That I delight to sing of Bliss;
And joyless too, but for my bent
To rhyme of Pleasures innocent;
And loveless, save that oft and long
I love to sing of Love—a loving Child of Song.
And thus beguiled, behold
How all my years from youth to manhood bold,—
Even like roes that on mount Hermon skip
Fast by the pilgrim,—in a careless train
Have I let pastward trip,
Ungathering aught that men call gain:
Howe'er the Gods in their divine
Appraisements, may regard this seeming fault of mine.
At all events, even so
Hitherto with me hath it fortuned,—though
Ever the while, even like a ship
Of Ophir, laden low
With many a golden strain:
Shorn have I also many a costly clip
From dream-flocks folded in the procreant brain,
And fed in Fable-Land—that bowery strip
Yet left of Eden, that one sole domain
Whose blossomy beauty no frore winters nip:—
Wherefore, I say, the world thinks—and even I
Myself think sometimes, with a faithless sigh,
That I have almost lived in vain,
Thus letting Fortune through my fingers slip,
With all that men call gain
Yes; almost lived in vain!
And most it moves me, does this self-disdain,
When some snob-Cræsus monkey-mean in feature—
Some Mammon-glorified inglorious creature,
That, like an upstart butterfly,
Was yesterday a grub,—flaunts flaring by past,
With purse-pride in his scoundrel eye
When me-ward it is cast!
For then, in sooth, it seemeth a disgrace
To have let so very a lump of earth
Outrun me (though the prize were nothing worth)
In any kind of race.
But soon again my heart fills—and I sing
Triumphantly again
Some rich-rhymed Orphic strain:
Gliding from the lyric string
Swiftly and freely as a dove's wing slips
Forth from its bough-perch in the shining Spring
When no cold influence nips.
Yea, so much stronger than my will
Is ever the Spirit of Song—that still
I only have my natural fling,
Am only happy—caroling.
Only am happy so,
Caroling ever as I go,
Happy and careless as a wood-born breeze
That does but gather as it onward slips
A wealth of sylvan melodies.
Yes: joy-lit eyes and love-dewed lips,
And things that company best with these—
Gleeful birds on wings of splendor,
Fresh-blown flowers divinely tender,
Streams in whose clear beauty dips
Many a bough of bordering trees,
Loaded thick with golden pips
Or murmurous with bees—
Drive from my thoughts all thought of Gain,
As 'twere indeed a thing most vain,
And much unfit to house within a Poet's brain.
Thus, whether for my worldly weal or woe,
From musing cometh all the gust I know,
From singing all the fond heart-ease.
Joy-flashing eyes and love-dewed lips!
Ever, I say, of these
That honey-bird, my Fancy, sips,
Arbored round with Eden-trees;
Or upon a silk-smooth cheek
Lying softly, lizard-sleek,
She suns contentedly in those
Her little lazy loving self,
Even like some fairy elf
Pillowed on a blushing rose:
And still, to perfect their success, I mould
These wonts of Fancy into songs of gold.
Still as I stand apart
In social loneliness of mind and heart,
Can I sometimes choose but sigh
That thus the world with me has gone ungarnered by?
Whilst other—duller men enjoyed
Its real loaves and firshes—
Each rosy substance of my rosiest wishes,
Even till it sweetness cloyed!
Yet, if a thought like this
Will mar at times my tuneful bliss,
By so much stronger than my will
Is still the Spirit of Song—that still,
Turning to the Muses' spring,
At once therein my heart I steep, at once again to sing
Of eloquent eyes,
That are of sunny thoughts the ever-sunny skies!
And gracious lips,
Dashed with such honey-dew as young Passion sips!
And what associate best with these—
Birds, and streams, and flowers, and trees
All starred with golden pips
And populous with bees.
But sometimes quitting
Themes so sweetly song-befitting:
Luminous fancies of luminous eyes
Whence love looks thought-veiled, as from sunset skies
The light shows richer for the half eclipse
It taketh so divinely-wise
From heaven's aérial draperies;
Sweet dreams that swarm round honeyed lips
Like honey-loving bees;
Glad birds, fresh flowers, clear streams, and trees
All starry with golden pips:—
Yea, sometimes quitting such delectable themes,
Though loth at first,—even as a happy breeze
That long hath dallied amid summer leas
A perfume-laden would-be loiterer seems,—
I clap to the yearnings of my lyre
Loud forth rushing wings of fire;
Or more to keep the sensual under,
Wrap them in soul-shaking thunder;
While for all spirits inginitely free
I sing of that great popular emprise
Of hardy progress, which, well-willed, to be
Tendeth the sooner in Man's destiny—
Willed by the bravely wise!
Or with as loud and bold a chime
I sing of that yet braver time,
When world-wide Justice from her alpine chair
Shall read at length in the rich-reddening skies
The gospel of her advent, and declare
The sacred sign of her epiphany there
Amid the purple dyes;
While all true men—the bravely wise
Shall seek her there triumphantly with feerless feet and free,
Where the prophet peaks arise
Out of the shattering mist—the phantom sea
Of old iniquity!
Through dense and rare shall seek her there,
Breathing with lion lungs the rigid mountain air
Of a supreme, upclimbing, God-great Liberty!
And thus employed, my purpose is most clinging:
For though unto the mole-eyed present I
Am almost nothing, I would be no less
Diverse from those who, Mammon's torch enringing,
Like moths, in their vain worship fly
Into its blaze at last—and blasted, die
The prey of a splendid wretchedness!
And something too for my harmonious singing,
To those diviner spiritual times
My Country yet shall know, and wisely knowing, bless!
Yea, something for the silver-pealing chimes,
And for the charm that never fadeth by
Of soul-enrishing rhymes!
A star of Poetry in the future's sky
Throbbing with deathless thought, and to the praise
That honeyed lips shall breathe and eloquent eyes shall raise!
With moods and aims thus rare and strong,
Albeit in lowliest station,
And nameless to the passing generation,
What wonder that, despite neglect and wrong,
I labor early—labor late and long,
Even like the Bards of old,
To fix each rich dream in as rich a song?
As one should set some priceless gem
In many-figured gold:
In The gold of a glorious diadem
Which on the mighty heads of a long line
Of Monarch Poets—each from his own mine
Of mental values, adding to the heritage
Adding A round of aulic lustres in his day,
Is thence foredoomed from storied age to age
To temper and to sway
The heart of a great People, great and sage—
Yea, ever growing more sublime and bright
From birth and nurture in the holier light
Shed forth on every hand—
Shed with a supersensual shine,
Flood-like, o'er the whole broad Land,
From absolute Truth's at last disclouded shrine.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 69-70.

lg.l: My soul is raying like a star!
My heart is happier than a bird!
And all to hear, through Fortune's jar,
One promissory word.
A sound as simple as the low
Quick sliding gurgle of a rill,
And yet of power to overflow
A world with blissful will.
Yea, such as makes even lowliest things
That dull and tuneless seemed before,
Mount as it were on lark-like wings,
And warble as they soar.
I feel as if all life and might
Had started on a loftier course;
As if all passion and delight
Were deepened at the source.
I feel as if the very air
Was breathen from the heart of Love;
As Pleasure in the sun's bright lair
Sat brooding like a dove.
A fruit tree fleeced with blossoms bright—
A fountain in the morning shine—
How exquisite is their delight?
So exquisite is mine.
A billow of the sunny sea—
A cloudlet of the sunny sky—
How wide is their felicity?
So widely blest am I.
O Beauty, even through a word,
What powers are thine, to raise and bless!
O Love, a seraph's voice is heard
In thy confiding Yes!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 70-71.

lg.l: Why smile you, as in sweet amaze,
My Mary—Mary mine, to see
These olden things in Nature's ways
So ever-fress to me?
To some, my lark-like indeed, these raptures fine
Might seem lark lark indeed to mount too lark like high;
But you at least—you, Mary mine,
Should guess the reason why.
If gazing at those evening skies,
I bathe as in their starry blue,
It is because thy loving eyes
Are glorying in it too.
And more, 'tis simply thence, I guess,
It seems too in itself so glad—
Yea, spirited with a lovingness
It one time never had.
Here too, how fondly do I trace
Yon shining river's winding stream,
For having seen it glass thy face
As in a happy dream.
Nor wonder, Mary, it should thence
With that sweet passion mix and roll,
The fountain of whose profluence
Lies deepest in my soul:
Lies deepest in my soul, indeed,
And under Joy's ideal skies
Doth flow in melody, and feed
Its flowers of Paradise.

div.p: The title "Love the Idealizer" is not repeated, nor is (presumably) the annotation "Copied into manuscripts".
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 71-72.

lg.l: It is the happy truth I sing,
When tracing Love's diviner laws,
I thus into my numbers bring
The why and the because.
Yes: why for ever in my view
So Muse-like looks the Wild-fig tree?
'Twas in its shade that first I knew
To rhyme sweet things of thee:
And also in its shade it was
That first I dared my love to tell—
And thus is compassed all the cause
Of its memorial spell.
Or o'er this fresh rose bending—why
Awakes such sweetness at my heart?
It gives to Love's poetic eye
Thy floral counterpart.
Nay, why to me seems any flower
Itself with actual passion warm
Because some influence of thy power
Hath passed into its form.
For Love is God's flower, Mary mine!
And Nature, tending up to God,
Treads on the skirts of the divine
Wherever Love hath trod.

div.p: The title "Love the Idealizer" is not repeated, nor is (presumably) the annotation "Copied into manuscripts".
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 72-73.

lg.l: To have the heart misread by One
Who is alone entreasured there,
Evokes a bitterness that none
May utter for despair.
Till anger brings a fierce relief,
And then wild words flash forth amain—
The lightnings of a stormy grief
That thunders in the brain.
But soon this tempest of the mind
Is hushed away by pleading fears,
And if it leaves a cloud behind,
That cloud dissolves in tears.
Till Love, self-reconciled, again
Becomes the exalter of our life,
Educing pèrfumes out of pain—
And rainbows out of strife.
Whence rather should we find claim find our part
Through loving, in them both, I ween,
Than bear about with us a heart
Where Love hath never been.
For none but natures cold and dry
Could feel self-satisfied, to know
Exemption from them in the high,
By resting in the low.

div.p: The title "Love the Idealizer" is not repeated, nor is (presumably) the annotation "Copied into manuscripts". Similarly, the annotation here "Final Copy" may be intended to apply to the first three parts as well.
