lg.l: Man's life is but a boastful weakness,
Pale with terrors unconfessed;
Yet Virtue may not lose her treasure,
And God is power exceeding measure—
Wherefore all is for the best
In the end—
In that certain Godward end
Tow'rds which all things, together working, tend.
The world is mountainous [unclear] with danger,
And with failure, and unrest;
Yet is it isled in the supernal,
And God is peace—yea, peace eternal—
Wherefore all is for the best
In the end.
The world is inter-pathed with errors,
And with follies unredressed;
Yet even wise men are forecasting,
And God is wisdom everlasting—
Wherefore all is for the best
In the end.
The world is sowed with lies for lucre—
Lies that every heart infest;
Yet fraud is overcome by duty,
And God is truth, and truth is beauty—
Wherefore all is for the best
In the end.
Power, peace, wisdom, truth, and beauty,
These are God—and here we rest
Secure though weak: for these attest
That Evil must be self-consuming,
A bale-fire Final Good to illuming—
All then—all is for the best
In the end—
In that certain Godward end
Tow'rds which all things, together working, tend.
But no man should less active be,
Believing thus,—as not less free
To use his strength, skill, wit, to reach
The things attractive unto each:
And somewhat good will ever run
From all that's well-designed and done,
Though out beyond our range it go,
(Because by God's hand prospered so)
Or wide of what we aimed at—lest
All should not be for the best.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 75-78.

body.p:
[The Comet here addressed was the great one of 1841 and the description of it applies, of course, only to its appearance but from a particular
stand-point in the Southern hemisphere It But it is
necessary to note this these facts, lest the youthful reader should suppose that
the Poet's imagination was making "bold holiday" in the expressions,
"The flaming steps
Of thy unspeakable speed, which, of itself,
Blows back the long strands of thy burning hair
Through half the arch of night." So far, however, from such being the case, these expressions, are
as descriptive of the Comet's tail, are to be taken literally.
For when, in declining, its necleus touched the horizon, this
tail, in the shape of a slightly opened fan, did absolutely reach
back nearly to the zenith.]

lg.l: Thy purpose, heavenly Stranger, who may tell
But Him who linked thee to the starry whole?
We see thou journeyest amid the worlds,
And that is all our vaunted Science knows
Of thy celestial moods. For of the birth
Of Motion, save as the primordial step
Of God's almighty and creative march
Out from his central rest, mankind even yet
But guess and speculate much as did of old
Egypt's dark seers,—observatoried high
On those star-pointing piles that crumbling stand
Amid grey wastes immensely stretching round
On all hands,—voiceless; even as in the dim
And desolate chambers of a doubly dead
Though monumental Past:—or, following these,
The Shephered Magi of the mystic East:
And this too with a [?]fath[unclear] faith less free, less raised
And thaumaturgic than was theirs, because
So cramped and cumbered with mechanic helps,
That palsying the wild wings of Wonder, keep
Her spirit down amid the dust and heat
Of so-called Matter—a vast eyeless Force
For ever grinding like a mill-wheel on!
And tend to make rank, even when they deaden least,

l.add: All poetry interdict:—or worse, to rank make

lg.l: Our bodily senses, with their objects, final;
As if in all the universe besides
Were nothing absolute—nothing purely God.
Wherefore, in this our darkness, be it ours
The more to muse of thee, in thy career,
As of some wandering symphony from amidst
Those highest stellar harmonies that track
Through infinite Space, and the great rounds of Time,
The aulic marches of Almighty Truth—
Or wild antiphony (at sure though long
Returning periods) striking in amongst
The planetary voices of Creation,
Singing together, in their sun-led choirs,
As through unmeasurable voids they wheel,
The God-taught anthem of eternal Order!
Thus may we muse of thee—and I, methinks,
With special privilege; for I indeed,
Here, in my own Land, wholly unforewarned
Of thy bright coming, chanced to see thee first:
Then having wandered forth, as was my wont,
To steep my heart in the rich sunset's pomp
Of visual splendors—oceaned as it were
In wide and far-withdrawing depths, that more
And more refined, as the tints mellower grew
Into recesses of a loveliness
Unutterably divine—yea, full of God!
Thus richly then my heart embathing—lo,
I saw the fading glories of the hour
Leave thee sole wonder of the twilight sky:
A wonder the more palpably revealed
As still, with gradual pace, the dark came on.
But now, since thou hast travelled high in heaven,
Myriads of wondering human spirits are out
Duly each night, with upturned looks that drink
The mystery of thy advent.
In thy last
Bright visitation, even thus thou saw'st
The young, the lovely, and the wise of Earth,—
A buried generation,—crowding out
Duly each night like these, with looks upturned
In wonder, to behold thee passing forth
Beyond the signs of Time—and then to know
In all the awful vastitude of heaven,
Thy place no more! And when the flaming steps
Of thy unspeakable speed, which of itself
Blows back the long strands of thy burning hair
Through half the arch of Night, shall rap thee forth
Into the dim of the Inane, beyond
Our utmost vision; all the eloquent eyes
Non-opened up in welcome though in wonder—
Eyes that are made habitually by Love
As tender as the turtle's, or that speak
The fervent soul and the majestic mind;—
All these, alas!—all these, ere thou once more
Shalt drive thus fulgently around the sun
Thy chariot of fire, fast closed in dust,
And mortal darkness, shall have given for aye
Their lustre to the Grave.
But human eyes
As many and beautiful—yea, more sublimed
And radiant in their passion, from a more
Enlarged communion with the Spirit of Truth,
Shall welcome the instead, mysterious Stranger,
When thou return'st anew.
And thus to think
Consoles us, even while we watch thee pass
Out of our times for ever—and thence to be
But seen again by those who shall convene
Over Above the darkling ashes that composed
When last thou swept within the gaze of the Earth,
The naturs they inherit:—Yea, although
Some selfish entertainment of a truth
At all times mournful, whisper us the while:
"So shall it be indeed; for God abides,
And Nature, born of his eternal power,
Must therefore share its dateless energy, as well—

l.add: Since Yea, all that which flows from the Eternal, must
If From a divine necessity alone,
Work with its cause for ever

lg.l: And wWork with it its cause for ever—still, alas!
Though thence derived, how fugitive and swift,
How vague and shadow-like, this life of Man!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 79-80.

lg.l: Both great and bountiful is he,
The Poet,—he whos glorious gift
Free of the world, and making free,
Heavenward on wings of melody
Can all things lift!
Yes, well may we account him great
Who through his every living line,
Doth, elevated, elevate,
And throw into the Mind's estate
A ray divine!
And bountiful as well as great,
Who still, in every song of power,
Commissioned, God-like, to create,
Bequeathes to Nature and to Fate
A rarer flower.

l.add: He He still, with spirit-riches rife,
Can plant bring into each passing hour
The worth of an immortal dower

lg.l: A rose of joy that cannot die!
A gem of light that nought may dim!
Some well of faith no drouth shall dry!
Some foretone of those anthems high
The Seraphs hymn!
Some glimpse of God—some mightier star
Isling Isled in Raying Hung in a supersensual sky!
Some glory without stint or bar—
A value overvaluing far
All Pride can buy!
All Pride can buy, or Avarice hoard,
Or earth-born influence attain!
A loveliness by Love adored—
A stuff by royal natures stored
As priceless gain!
Then great and bounteous both is he,
The Poet,—he whose glorious gift,
Free of the world, and making free,
Heavenward on wings of melody
Doth all things lift!
Yea, whatso he hath seen or heard—
As at the morning's golden rise,
The lark from his ground-nest of stirred,
And lifted, till he flames—a bird
Of Paradise!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 80-81.

lg.l: Paler, paler, day by day,
Waxeth wordless Eva Gray;
Wasting—wasting, day by day,
Like a thin white cloud away.
And how shall those who wish her well,
Lift the shadowy pall that fell
Around her through Love's darkened spell?
Would they have her feast with Song?
Its wild voices but prolong
Through Memory's echoes Passion's wrong!
Would they, to beguile her leisure,
Sweet reliefs in Music measure?
Music but dreams of foregone pleasure.
Would they lure her where the Spring
Gives the unhurt heart to wing
Up heavenward, like a lark, and sing?
Still paler, paler, day by day,
Waxeth gentle Eva Gray;
Ever wasting, day by day,
Like a thin white cloud away!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 81-82.

lg.l: I love him so,
That though his face I ne'er might see,
In the assurance that he so loved me
This heart of mine would glow
With pulses sweeter than the sweetest be
That colder ones can know.
I love him so,
That to my thought 'twere sweet to sleep
Even in death, believing he would keep
With solemn step and slow,
In sabbath memory my Grave, and weep
For Her who slept below.
I love him so,
That all desires when he is by
Shrink even from the import of a sigh:
As flowers unseen that grow,
Being mute, unseen remain; as in the sky
Are stars that none may know.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 82.

lg.l: A Streamlet is a bright and beauteous creature
In some wide desert, where it keeps a part 'tis blest the more
Of each wayfarer's heart In way-worn Memory's core;;
The Star of Evening is a gracious feature
Instinct, as 'twere, with all the love that eyes
Have ever looked through, looking at the skies.
And hence one emblems in its beauteous being
The memory of a love that in my heart
Flowed gratefully apart;
The other, to my spiritual seeing,
The perpetuity of that love's white grace
Yet, as a radiance, in some heavenly place.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 82-83.

lg.l: Away—away she plunges,
With her white sails o'er her spread,
Like the sheety clouds that gather
On some hill's piny head!
Still away she plunges rampant,
Like a lion roused to wrath,
And the late-proud wave lies humbled
In the foam-track of her path.
Ye ho! my galant sailors
Wear her head from off the land:
As his steed obeys the Arab
How she gives to the hand!
Like a soul the from earth departing
Now she leaves the coast behind,
And the Deep is her wide dwelling,
Her wild spouse the gipsy Wind!
Then fill we a full measure
To the friends we left to day,
Whose kind thoughts shall hover o'er us
On our wave-foaming way;
Where diurnally remind us
Shall the same bright-brimming rite,
Of the fond eyes that yearned blessings
When we last beheld their light.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 83-84.

lg.l: When heaven is waxing grey, Mary,
The dawning isles between,
And the stars are paling fast away
In Morn's eclipsing sheen:
While the broad red sun is breaking then
From out the burning sea,
All life to gladness waking—then
My spirit longs for thee.
And when in noontide strength, Mary,
He bears bares his beaming blades,
Till Nature's busy tribes at length
Lie panting in the shades:
While the sea, like white fire glowing then,
Though cool and fresh it be,
Is only heard far flowing—then
I'm lonely without thee.
When clouds in crimson dyed, Mary,
Bedrape heaven's western gate,
Till like a rare and royal bride
Eve enters there in state:
While yon cliff-born kids, all prancing then,
Are mirrored in the sea,
In its wide joy out glancing—then
I love to think of thee.
And when Night's throned again, Mary,
And all the stars are met,
To sing their old creation-strain
Ere Hesperus be set:
While the silver Moon is beaming then,
And in the silent sea
Her other Self is dreaming—then
My heart is full of thee.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 84-85.

lg.l: Where Beauty is smiling
With love undenied,
And gladness is flowing
From Pleasure's hill-side—
Whatever of charming,
Thus absent, I see,
I can turn from it, Mary,
To think upon thee.
When blasts of affliction
Blow cold on my rest,
And the pang that will sleep not
Is loud in my breast;
Still, however clinging
These troubles may be,
I can turn from them, Mary,
To think upon thee.
When Weariness sleepeth,
And Care is at rest;
When Happiness nestles
With all it loves best:
Then as the Moon gazes
Entranced on the sea,
My soul, o'er thy dwelling,
Dreams down upon thee.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 85-86.

lg.l: A Huntress born to Nature
Through the might of olden lore,
Lithely on bounding, lightens right past me,
Full as the morning of hurry and vigor,
Wherever the rock-floods roar:
—See her bow! I see it plain!
And shafted quiver balanced nice!
See her robes, blown back amain,
Though looped in front by a sure device,
Sweeping behind her, like the train
Of a Bird of Paradise!
Or where the forest shadows
Are dew-silvered by the morn,
Lonely forth roaming, not long do I listen,
Till suddenly sounding up, merry and mellow,
There hear I her mystic horn:
—Then her buskined limbs how white
They glance, as past she boundeth there!
See her bow—a curve of light
Across her arm upraised and bare!
And see how backward streameth bright
The torrent of her hair!
Or where the vales are sleeping
In a silent silver sleep,
Musefully strolling, not long am I lonely,
Ere mystical melody, billow on billow,
Wells from each echoey steep:
—Then an arc of rainbow light
Suddenly spans some viny glade,
And there I see her Presence bright,
Disclouding Bound beaming from the deeper shade,
All girt with dancing Nymphs in white
And festal robes arrayed!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 86-87.

lg.l: When broad o'er her hill-top hangs Eve's glowing star,
Comes a Spirit of beauty, as if from afar;
To dream through the gloaming's heart-hushing degrees,
And richen the odor-sweet breath of the breeze:
To mellow the echoes that bleat from the hills
Where While the shepherds are folding their flocks by the rills;
In the wild woods to deepen the dove's gentle voice,
To live in all life, in all gladness rejoice.
Thus out of the sunset, as if from afar,
Comes it ever, as now, with that broad-hanging star:
Yea, 'tis breathing around, it is glowing above,
That spirit of beauty—the Spirit of Love.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 87-88.

lg.l: The dulcimer was sounding
From within a mystic grove,
Where, strown with blooms, rose gleaming pure
A sculptured shrine of Love,
Round which tall youths and maidens fair
Went bounding in a row
In the flowery dale of Sibma
Four thousand years ago.
And we, a group glad-dancing
On this fair Australian earth
Have met for the same Spirit here
To raise our rosey mirth;
To know it as those mouldered hearts
Did its sweet influence know,
In the flowery dale of Sibma
Four thousand years ago.
And in the days far coming
Upon destiny's dim wing,
Some loving band thus meeting all
Amid the blooming Spring,
May muse of us as we of them
Whose happy hearts did glow,
In the flowery dale of Sibma
Four thousand years ago.
Thus Love, though old in worship,
Is in presence ever young;
The same wherever prevalent—
The same wherever sung:
As now with us it moved with them
Who bounded in a row,
In the flowery dale of Sibma
Four thousand years ago.
But thus too, of all passion
What is sung alone abides—
All else elapses, like a dream,
On Being's fatal tides:
This Rhyme perhaps is all that now
Is flavored here below,
With the love that glowed in Sibma
Four thousand years ago.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 88-89.

lg.l: 'Tis the early Summer season
When the skies are clear and blue,—
And When wide warm fields are glad with corn
As green as ever grew,
And upland growths of wattles
Engolden all the view.
O there is a conscious joyance
In a heaven so clearly blue!
And it must be a felt happiness
That thus comes blooming through
Great Nature's mother-heart,— when
The golden year is new!
When the woods are whitened over
By the jolly cockatoo,
Or swarm with birds as beautiful
As ever gladdened through
The shining hours of Time,— when
The golden year was new.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 89.

lg.l: Tell me not of maids Italian, or the stately dames of Spain,
Let their beauty's burning semblance fire some other brain!
But a gentle English Maiden,—lily fair,—a flower of light;
She has all the dainty graces whereof I would write.
Smiles as rich and rare as rubies—utterance purely feminine;
Heaven-blue eyes that orb affection as in spheres divine!
And with these a modest stillness, all the dearer that it seems
An unwitting revelation of most loving dreams.
Sweet and lowly flowers that glare not are the latest to decay;
Stars that bring their blessing nearest have the mildest ray;
He who visioned Desdemona was sweet Mary Arden's child;
He who pictured Una loved an English Maiden mild.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 90.

lg.l: O love is passing sweet,
When 'tis ours indeed to meet
With a golden hearted Maid,
Nothing loth, and not afraid
To indrink its Orphic fire,
Till her whole soul, like a lyre,
Thrill and beat
To the thought, and with the feeling,—
Love is sweet.
'Tis like a sunset sky
Blushing beauty, to the eye;
It is like a summer wind
Breathing odors, to the mind;
It is like the fervent roll
Of rich music to the soul;
And we cry
Let us always love, or failing,—
Let us die!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 90-91.

lg.l: A Voice for ever sweet and low
Like the flute-tones of a brook—
Richly familiar,
Lik a loved song given to flow
From some belovéd heart-valued book;
Day by day was at my side
Amid the hills where I was born,
And if it went at eventide,
It came again at morn:
And 'twas the last that blest me, when
I wandered from my native glen.
Again returned—again I hear
Brooks in flow that then I heard—
Wildly familiar,
Youth's glad dreams seem warbling near
In every happy bird.
Yet the more I feel alone
That round me these known things rejoice,
Because I miss 'mid every tone
That ever-gentle still-pren present once accordant Voice,
Which I may listen for again
In all the weary world—in vain!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 91-92.

lg.l: I envy no greatness, I bow to no pride,
I am lord of what none can be lord of beside,
Though, lonely and landless, I dwell in no more
Than a Lodge where the wild woods hang shadowing o'er.
And Love, if heroic, right healthful and strong,
Like the passion whose amaranth bloometh in song,
As bees hive their honey, it sweetness might store
In a Lodge where the wild woods hang shadowing o'er.
And a Poet, like Shakspere, the heart-seer profound,
Or like Milton, whose genius but heaven could bound,
Might build up his judgment and chasten his lore
In a Lodge where the wild woods hang shadowing o'er.
For where there's a free heart, blood royal is there,
And true love's a honey-bee everywhere;
While the Muse never heeds how we house what she gives,
Since no Dwelling is mean where a thorough man lives.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 92.

lg.l: Wrongly she loveth, doth true-hearted Carry,
Loving a vagrant, her kindred aver;
But all gone adrift must her faith be, ere Harry—
Wild Harry the Rover's a vagrant to her!
Oft doth the wayward one make her feel lonely,
Wilding away like a wave of the main;
But she knows that he loves, and loveth her only,
And so she forgives him again and again.
Quick come the glad day—O were it to-morrow!
When in Love's haven her wild one shall rest:
But living or dying, in joy or in sorrow,
She'll love him as now, and in loving do best.
So must it fortune, since tried love that's blenched not,
Meriteth heaven on heaven's own plan;
And so must it fortune, since tried faith that's wrenched not,
Is ever the germ of the Angel in man.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 93-94.

lg.l: I see, as in vision,
How face to face I stood
Long years ago with Dora
In yon green wood:
Long years ago with Dora,
The gentle and the good—
The Angel of my destiny,
In Yon Green Wood.
I said not that I loved her,
But well she understood
My bosom's beating secret
In yon green wood:
I said not that I loved her,
Although I wished I could
Have told her so a thousand times
In Yon Green Wood.
The budding joys of fancy
Were like the maidenhood
Of morning blooms ungathered,
In yon green wood:
Of morning blooms All blooming and ungathered,
While face to face we stood,
'Mid Hope's untrampled Eden both,—
In Yon Green Wood.
It saw affection's dawning,
And love's first purple mood,
And then two souls grow one soul—
Did yon green wood:
Alas! my heart is yearning,
Nor wonder that it should,
Since what hath been can be no more
In Yon Green Wood.
As somewhat aye regretful
By destiny ensued,
For dreamers such as we were
In yon green wood:
Life to that heart hath spoken
Through many a mournful mood,
"Love's sweetest, wildest charm was left
In Yon Green Wood.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 94-95.

lg.l: Dark is her cheek, but her blood's rich blush
Comes through its dusk with a sunset flush,
While Joy, like a prairie bee, slaketh its drouth
At the red honey cup of her smiling mouth.x
And her wild eyes glow, like twin stars meteors—there,
'Neath the streaming storm of her night-black hair.
And ever I pride in my forest choice
The more while I list to her bird-like voice
Warbling old songs in her own wild speech,
But aye with this new burden still added to each:
Who'll pity—who'll comfort the dark wood-dove,
When the white hawk leaves her—to die of love!
O then, by the artless tears that rise
'Neath the downcast lids of her gleaming eyes—
By the truthfully tender and touching grace
That boding passion then lends to her face—
I swear in the very wild spirit of love,
Never to leave her!—my Indian Dove!

div.p:
x In allusion to the red cup—a flower (or rather, I should
say, the flower) of the American Prairies.
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 95-96.

lg.l: When a simple English maiden
Nested warm in Wilmicote,
Singing like a lark, when trailing
Heavenward up its morning note—
Did no English ear that listened,
Even then,—foretouched by Fame,—
Tremble to the prophet music
Fountain-headed in thy name:
Mary Arden?
Tell me, shade of Mary Arden!
Shade of Shakspere's Mother, tell me.
Or to thee thyself, O tell me,
Did no dazzling vision come,
(Like a sunburst over Stratford,
Burning up its boreal gloom)
Of the bardic grandeurs waiting
On thy matron fate, when He
Who in time would call thee Mother,
Should all time's Subjector be:
Mary Arden?
Tell me, shade of Mary Arden!
Shade of Shakspere's Mother, tell me.
Then a Mother we behold thee,
With that Babe upon thy breast—
That great nascent soul so bird-like
Babbling in its fragrant nest:
O what feelings sweetly human—
O what instincts mildly wise—
Sucked he from those mother-fountains?
Drew he from those mother-eyes?
Mary Arden!
Tell me, shade of Mary Arden!
Shade of Shakspere's Mother, tell me.
But shall we, now spirit-basking
In the noon-blaze of his fame,
Fail to read a sign prophetic
In thy lovely maiden Name?
No: it is the Star that trembled
O'er a royal Poet's birth,
And amongst immortal Maries
Second to but one on earth!
Mary Arden!
Glory be to Mary Arden!
Shakspere Mother! England's Mary!x

lg.l: With a resplendent Eastern bride
Like a Houri at my side,
And music round us swelling,
'Mid odors of so rare a steam
That viewless Spirits of love they seem,
Dwell I, through a radiant Dream
In a rich Orient dwelling.
Near a fair fountain flashing high
In the pleasure court we lie,
Each on a gorgeous pillow:
The columned water, mounting, breaks
In outward curves and falling flakes,
Till the whole a picture makes
As of a crystal willow.
Wide round us gallaried walls extend,
Pierced with arcs and aisles that bend
On wreathen pillars slender;
While, hung in every vista,—lo,
Such clouds of blazoned banners glow,
As in very semblance show
A constant sunset splendor.
And virgin faces, darkly bright
Like the countenance of Night
Seen in its starry glory,
All ministrant, around us throng
And breathe their beauty pathos into song,
Or in tones, as rich, prolong
Some wild rich-worded story.
Till hark! through many voices—one
Like a gush of gold doth run:
"Why—why should kindred sever?
Our life is this perpetual feast
Of being, from all care released—
Sunny souls are for the East:
Then dwell with us for ever!"

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 98-99.

lg.l: It was, I well remember,
The merry Springtime, when
Young Dora, in the eventide,
Came singing up the Glen:
Came singing up the Glen,
Till one many-warbled part,
Like a subtle stream of vocal fire
Ran glowing through my heart.
A fond resolve, long cherished,
Till then I might control;
Till then—but oh! that witching strain
It drew it from my soul!
It drew it from my soul,
And she did not say me nay,
And the world of love was all the world
To us that happy day.
I'm happy now in thinking
How happy I was then,
When tow'rds the glowing west my love
Went homeward down the Glen:
Went homeward down the Glen,
While my comfort surer grew,
Till methought the old-faced hills all looked
As they were happy too.
All happy, for that Dora
And I so happy were
All happy, for that Human Love
Had breathed its spirit there!
Had breathed its spirit there,
And had made them conscious grow
Of the part they bore in that sweet time—
That happy Long Ago.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 99-101.

body.p:
[It will be remembered by many Colonists, that about five and
twenty years ago (dating back from 1867.) a party of Stockmen (several
of whom were afterwards hanged for the crime) made wholesale slaughter
of a small tribe of defenceless Blacks—to the number, it is believed,
of more than forty;—heaping their bodies, as they butchered them like
cattle, upon a large fire kindled for the purpose. Of this doomed
tribe, one woman only, with her infant, as it appeared subsequently from
the evidence in the case, escaped the Whiteman's vengeance. And the
Poem is supposed to describe the grief and record the ejaculations of
this Mother, after she has fled to a considerable distance from the
scene of the massacre, and when weared and overtaken by the
Night.]

lg.l: Yet farther would I fly, my Child,
To make thee safer yet,
From the Whiteman's so unsparing
Dread hand, all murder-wet!
Yet bear thee on as I have borne
With stealthy strides wind-fleet,
But the dark suts up the Forest,
And thorns are in my feet.
O moan not!—I would give this braid
That once bound Hibbi's brow,
Were it but for a single palmful
Of water for thee now.
Ah! spring not to his name;—no more
To help us may he come;
He is smouldering into ashes
Beneath the blasted gum:
All charred and blasted by the fire
The Whiteman kindled there,
And fed with our slaughtered kindred
Till heaven-high went its glare.
O moan not! &c
And but for thee, I would their fire
Had eaten me as fast!
Hark!—hark! do I hear his death cry
Yet lengthening up the blast?
But no—when his bound hands had signed
The way that we should fly,
On the roaring pyre flung bleeding,
I saw thy Father die!
O moan not! &c
No more shall his loud tomahawk
Be plied for our relief to win [unclear] our cheer
Or the shining fish-pools darken
Beneath their his shadowing Chief! spear!
The fading tracks of his fleet foot
Shall guide not as before,
And the mountain Spirits mimic
His hunting call no more.
O moan not!—I would give this braid,
Thy Father's gift to me,
Were it but for a single palmful
Of water now for thee.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 101-103.

lg.l: Sir Gilbert Blount's is a happy man,
And happier is he aye,
To think his sole Child's Cora's lovesome eyes
Grow lovelier day by day:
Two violets in a shady place,
Where two are seen alone—
Two well-springs filled with heaven's blue face,
'Neath willowy fringes shown.
And so it hath been ever forth
Since first his heart could say:
"A lily of Love's green Valley
Is born to me this day."
Sir Gilbert Blount's is a jovial man—
A jovial and a free!
But why hath he provoked to day
This storm of minstrelsy?
It is as if his heart had run
Stag-wild with mirth and wit,
And he would have old Time's grey one
Go bounding on with it!
But did you ask the reason why,
The happy man would say:
"My lily of Love's green Valley
Is seven years old to day."
Sir Gilbert was a jovial man—
A jovial and a free!
But silent in his hall is now
The voice of minstrelsy:
It may be, he hath felt his prime
A-wearing from him fast,
And so would make the coming time
Redeem the heedless past.
But did you ask the reason why,
The altered man would say:
"My lily of Love's green Valley
Is withering away."
Sir Gilbert was a stalwart knight,
And sturdy as a tree,
Though genial as the warmth of wine
In pleasant company:
And can it be that he hath so
Misused a year of time,
That few his face again would know
Who saw him in his prime?
Ah! that is not the reason why
His head is turned so grey:
Has withered now away!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 103-104.

lg.l: Ah! what in all the world might move
My wearied being to the core,
As once could Love—that morning love
Which I, alas! may feel no more;
When Dora, fonder for the theft,
In haste would meet me—soon to part
With backward raying looks, that left
Their brilliance in my heart!
Her presence made all nature bright,
And all within, as all without;
Or absent, she was one delight
To dream ten thousand things about!
Alike to me in shine or shower
The day and night away might roll,
While the sweet spirit of her power
Was regnant in my soul.
Ah! what in all the world might move
My wearied being to the core,
As could that Love—the morning love
Which I, alas! may feel no more?
The mountain measure of its might,
Its joy so ocean-like and vast,
Can now be but a thought delight—
A Vision of the Past.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 104-105.

lg.l: Many and many a day has flown
Since standing together were we
Gramachree,
Under the shadowy wild Fig-tree,
While the suns of the Past in the red west shone;
And yet how my distant heart is thrilled
Like a harp that is swept by the breeze alone
Whenever I'm thinking of thee,
Gramachree,
And my head with a dim wild stir is filled
Like the sound remote of a sooming sea.
And so is it always with me,
Gramachree,
When I think of the Past and of Thee,
Gramachree,
And so must it evermore be,
Gramachree,

When my soul dreameth back—dreameth back
after thee!
'Tis a fond feeling of happier days,
(When standing together were we,
Gramachree,
Under the shadowy wild Fig-tree,
Close hid from the low sun's lengthening rays)
That thrills and sweetens within my breast
Like a breeze that afar from its Eden strays,
Whenever I'm thinking of thee,
Gramachree,
And this dim brain-stir is the wild unrest
Of a moaning and homeless memory.
And so is it always with me,
Gramachree,
When I think of the Past and of Thee
Gramachree,
And so must it evermore be,
Gramachree,

When my soul dreameth back—dreameth back after
thee?
Ah! that the beautiful Spirit of Love,
That once, when together stood we,
Gramachree,
Under the shadowy wild Fig-tree,
Sat homed as it were in the branches above
Impassioning all our sympathies,
Should be wandering now like the arkless dove,
Or should then have been only to be,
Gramachree,
Thus refelt in the stir of Thought's mystic breeze,
And the shell-like murmurs of Memory.

div.p: The annotation is carried over editorially from the first poem on p. 103.
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 105-106.

lg.l: I wandered east, I wandered west
For long years, hoping yearly,
That Fortune at last would give me rest,
With the One I loved most dearly:
Hoping ever it might be so,
As the spirit of fancy inclined me,
So purely my heart's queen long, long ago
Was the Maiden I left behind me.
To wander aye would seem my lot,
To wander aye, though weary,
Striving in vain to compass what
My spirit hath prized most dearly:
No longer I deem it may be so,
For fancy no longer can blind me—
Ah! well-a-day, for the long, long ago
And the Maiden I left behind me.
It may be, had we mated been,
And I had never wandered,
The Eden of Love ere this had seen
Its beauty and bloom all squandered!
But oh! in my heart, a vacant ache
At thought of the Past will remind me,
How lonely it is for the sad sweet sake
Of that Maiden I left behind me.

div.p: The annotation is carried over editorially from the first poem on p. 103.
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 106-107.

lg.l: Heaven's whole round was bright as now,
When homeward, long ago, I trod:
Blest!—having won my Dora's vow
To love me next to God!
And as homeward then I went
Upon that happy far night,
Up, into the lit firmament
My glowing spirit rayed, and lent
Even unto the star-light.
But years are gone—and Dora now
Is gone too, under the green sod:
No!—gone to Paradise with her vow
To love me next to God.
And as here aloft I gaze
As on that happy far night,
Heaven's whole round is all a-blaze,
And up my spirit, yearning, rays—
But high above the star-light.

div.p: The annotation is carried over editorially from the first poem on p. 103.
Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 107-108.

lg.l: Ah, me!—but in this sunset hour,
One sad thought with its serious sting
So pricks me, that all outward power
For pleasure, can small pleasure bring.
How full of God those evening skies
Arrayed in utter loveliness:
I say—but think how many eyes
Are wet, hearts aching, none the less.
Nay, hearts are aching, eyes are wet
The more that they so richly glow,
Since in the Past some glory set
To leave them in the dark of woe.
To leave them dark, and such a tinge
O'er every after sunset throw,
That it should only seem to fringe
The pall of a dead Long Ago
Ah! well-a-day: but so it is;
To think is almost to dispair!
And pain and loss we cannot miss,
And sorrow—it is everywhere.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 108-109.

lg.l: Still his little grave she seeketh
In her mother-sorrow wild!
Hush! while in her heart she speaketh
To the spirit of her child:
"Oh, were we not to one another
Once the sum of all sweet gain?
Say then—say unto thy Mother,
Shall we ever meet again?
Darling! shall we meet again,
Knowing, loving one another?"
Nothing but the wind is heard,
Sighing in reply,
When the long grave-grass is stirred
As it floweth by.
"Ah! what weary, weary sorrows
Have I known through loss of thee
And what comfortless to-morrows
Wait me in this misery!
And were we not to one another
Once the sum of all sweet gain?
Say then—say unto thy Mother,
Shall we ever meet again?
Darling! shall we meet again,
Knowing, loving one another?"
Still the wind alone is heard
Sighing in reply;
When the long grave grass is stirred
As it floweth by.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 109-110.

lg.l: O wert thou mine, belovéd Girl!
How rich I were with such a mate,
Albeit around me still should whirl
The most injurious waves of Fate:
No more disgust, no more despair,
Should snake-like coil about my life!
So could'st thou bless me, didst thou dare
To be a Poet's Wife.
Before us see how frets the sea
Of Being—a dread changeful state!
And think ere thou putt'st forth with me
Where heart alone can cope with Fate;
How many new and clinging cares,
World-born to an unworldly life,
Must be her crown of thorns, who dares
To be a Poet's Wife.
A spirit gentle and resigned
Must speak her boundless faith in love,
And in the temper of her mind
The lioness obey the dove:
A heart above mere Fashion's shows,
And All the petty prides pomps of life;
These must be her high dower, who goes
To be a Poet's Wife!
And these are thine, beloved Girl! One!
And I, secure of such a mate,
Believe that Love's full risen sun
Can fill with light the dark of Fate;
And that all needful toil and care
Shall breathe for me this psalm of life:
Dare all for her who all could dare—
A destined Poet's Wife.x

div.head: I Would Get Me a New Love.

lg.l: I would get me a new love, the old fire is out!
I would get me a new love ere Spring comes about;
That as in her warm arms the fields all re-bloom,
My lone heart may awaken from coldness and gloom.
O there's nothing in nature like love when 'tis new;
And there's nothing in fortune like love when 'tis true!
But my passion for Meg was a fire that's burnt out,
And I'd get me a new love ere Spring comes about.
I would get me a new love, less Custom's cold slave;
And I'd get me a new love more earnest and brave!
To pure to mistrust me, too noble to doubt—
I would get such a new love ere Spring comes about.
But if such a new love I nowhere may get,
I'd as lief be thus lonely—nay, lonelier yet!
Than have one like the old love, just playing a part,
With a flare in her fancy, but ice at her heart.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 111-112.

lg.l: "O that yon Moon, when thus silverly beaming
Might come through the spells of my passionate dreaming,
In the guise of a Lady fair, blessing and blest,
And pillow my head on her beautiful breast!
"O that yon Star which in heaven is whitest,
Might come when Love's visions around me are brightest,
Like a fancy-pale Maiden dream-drawn from her rest—
And rap me away to its home in the West!
"O that the Spirit of music by flowing,
When Love's light, the test of all beauty, is glowing,
Might take such a shape as my heart can concieve,
And breathe in my arms like a daughter of Eve!
"O that some snowy-wing'd Angel of heaven
But once to the sight of my spirit were given,
So rich in the beauty born with her on high,
That to love her were death—I would love her and die!"
Thus sang a Poet Boy wandering lonely,
Whilst yet he had tasted life through his dreams only;
Born deep into beauty, of Beauty he dreamed
As the Queen of all being—how vainly it seemed!
For the Moon with pale love of the day-god was beaming,
And the Star of some star that attracts was dreaming,
And the Music remained an invisible birth,
And no Daughter of Bliss might descend to the earth:
Yet not all vainly his spirit was yearning burning
Tow'rds the rare and the deathless;—the fruits of its yearning
Had blossom in Eden, nor shall they be hurled
Away with the perishing weeds of the world!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 112-113.

lg.l: A sylphic form and angel face,
A young life void of sin—
The outward lineaments and grace
Of purity within:
Such was my spirit's visioned joy
When I was a dreaming Boy.
A figure rich in pleasant health,
A warm heart and a good—
The summer attributes and wealth
Of thorough womanhood:
Such was my spirit's yearned-for truth
When I was a lonely Youth.
And in my manhood it may be
I have not chanced to find
Even One who realised to me
The Lady of my mind:
Yet therefore feel I not as cross'd—
Nothing but a Dream is lost.
While in the power that dreamt there lives
A love-creating ray,
Worth all that Fortune ever gives
Or ever takes away:
Inspiring oft a genial rhyme
Even 'mid the snows of Time.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 113-114.

lg.l: What so sweet upon the earth
As Love, when it is new;
Or what so golden in its worth,
If only Love were only true?
What like Friendship for a shield
'Gainst want, and riches too;
Or what such summer fruit might yield,
If Friendship were but true?
What like Faith, whose vision brings
The gates of heaven in view,
With Love and Friendship for its wings,
If all alike were true?
All alike of trusty stuff—
And why are they not so?
There surely still were room enough
For Misery here below.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 114-115.

body.p:
[The native bird thus called, or more commonly, the honey-sucker, is quit
a curiosity in natural history. Its bill is a mere tube, about as large in girth as a
darning needle, and nearly as long. It is, in fact, nearly equal in length to
all the rest of the bird's body, the tail (as in the case of all fowls with very long bills)
being short and stumpy, like that of the kingfisher. In this tube there is a sort of
natural pump-sucker, and the bird is thus enabled to come at the honey which is
contained in the deep cups of the mountain bugle and bell flowers. Hence the
habitat of the honey-bird is always to be found in those localities (invariably
mountainous) which give birth in profusion to flowers of the kinds above mentioned,
and of others kinds akin to them. In such places only grow these deep-cupped flowers,
and in such places only is there a tube-billed bee-bird to batten upon their sweetness;
so cruriously adaptative in her principles is our wonderful mother, Nature.

And here, no doubt, the question will occur to some one: But having
equipt this bird in a manner so peculiar, how does Nature manage to preserve its
being during the winter season, when there are no flowers? In answer to this
I have only a guess to offer—namely, that perhaps it becomes and lies dormant
in cold frosty weather, for it certainly has not sufficient strength of wing for migration
to any such distance as would reach to a climatic difference of temperature.

It should be added, that though the bill of the honey-sucker is a mere
tube, the bird is not therefore wholly dumb, but contrives to blow through it, as it hops
about amongst the flowers, a somewhat slender yet agreeable note.]

lg.l: Wherever in some mountain bower
There blooms a honey-yielding flower,
There too dwells a Bird, to sup
Out of its delicious cup,
And sing at times, lest it should be
O'er fed into satiety.
And so, wherever Loveliness
Dwells secluded—dwells to bless,
Not dazzle; there some destined Spirit
Feeding on its lucious merit,
Can at peace with passion be
Only through glad Poetry.

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, pp. 115-116.

lg.l: Hold to the right, and be loyal in all things:
This is of manhood the only true plan!
Hold to thy faith, or in great or in small things:
This is the statute God layeth on man.
Build not thy structures upon the world's notion
That deemeth all good may compassed through pelf:
Nothing in fortune is worth our devotion
That any can buy, as not owning itself.
Nothing in fortune, and nothing in nature,
That time can impair or base interest mould!
But whatso hath part in the spirit's God-stature
Is absolute value, and cannot be sold.
Perish the wisdom that makes us time-servers!
Perish the virtue that's gain in disguise!
Leave them to comrades, to weaklings, to and dastardly swervers—
Yea, make them thy scorn, as one valiantly wise.
Fear not, when wrong Power contriveth undue laws,
That right shall be fountained in manhood no more;
Blench not, when traitors abandon a true cause—
The truth of it liveth with God as before!
Nations benighted by failure, believe not;
But wait for the morning do thou—and believe:
Mammon's high castes ban the poor, and relieve not;
But make God thy debtor do thou—and relieve.
Yea, to their cause, in God's name, and the devil's,
Hold, if thou must, when contending with Pride!
Led by that wisdom whose rule only levels
The lofty, by raising the worth it has tride tried.
Live—die for thy own, be they many or few men—
Following Love even into the grave!
Thus, and thus only, can any be true men,
Faithful in all things—fraternal and brave!

div.p: Mitchell Library, Harpur MS A88, p. 117.

lg.l: Old Sam Terry went to a Church meeting
Where he met from the parsons a great deal of greeting,
Because he could give them so much, if he chose there,
But as he stood bowing on his old gouty toes there,
All on a sudden he made a great snort they say,
Alarming the belles and the beaux there!
Let a great f–t too;—then fell all amort that day:
Dying the next, and going—God knows where!
